eventName: In memory of Carole And Pauline Osment And Meaney
pageSummary: Shaving my head because The absolute amazing support and work they do!
pageSummaryWhy: The absolute amazing support and work they do!
story:
Hi Guys!

So I'm shaving my head! For my Grandma, Granny and a friend

Carole Osment - Grandma -17/12/2017 my grandma died of Cancer back in 2017 and Macmillan were ever present through all of it! They were absolutely fantastic even paying for my Grandmas care towards the end! 

Pauline Meaney - Granny -16/11/2020 my granny died of cancer recently and fortunately Macmillan weren't needed as there was Hospice care @ home already in place. Who did a fantastic Job!

This year my partners friend was diagnosed with cancer aswell and fingers crossed they are at the tail end and on the up! 

Macmillan do such a fantastic job nationwide and their care is absolutely incredible! They take such good care of the patient as well as the family and support you all in every way they can! I'd love to give something back to these outstanding people!

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
As a family we would like to show our gratitude and appreciation to the whole Macmillan staff who cared for Sam during her treatment.

The care, knowledge, understanding and patience given to her during this last year made such an impact.

Macmillan Cancer Support is a charity that was close to her heart, and one she would want to raise as much money for as possible so they can continue doing the incredible work they do.

Macmillan don’t stop at diagnoses, they have highly dedicated teams that help each and every patient through their journey, as well as offering incredible support to families. Support from understanding a diagnoses, through tough treatment and even as a shoulder to cry on or an ear to listen.

We ask that if you want to do something meaningful in remembrance of Sam, please consider donating to a much loved and deserving charity such as Macmillan Cancer Support.

Thank you

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Hi guys, Rvdge_ here!


I have set this page up to try and raise funds for the wonderful charity that is MacMillanm Cancer Support. I'm sure most of you are aware of the work they do, but just in case you don't they use their funding and donations made by kind individuals to help in any which way a family may need in times of loss or hardship caused by the C word.


We , as a family, have suffered with loss of family members and friends over the years and I always wished there was something I could have done to help whichever way I could. In the recent weeks, I have become fortunate enough to build a small community on Twitch, a video game streaming service, and upon seeing an advertisement by MacMillan appealing for gamers to use the resources available to them to use their hobby to try and raise some money for the charity, I instantly signed up and accepted the challenge. I have gamed since the age of 3, it has always been a big part of my life and i thought Ii would be ridiculous for me to not try and do some good and help those who need it most whilst doing what I would probably be doing anyway! Any amount, big or small, is vastly appreciated and I, just like those who will benefit from any help given, cannot thank you enough!


Regards,


Rvdge_

story:
Thanks for supporting our fundraising. 

This Christmas, we feel it may be better to give a small donation to our charity of choice than give staff or friends presents. We feel it is better to help others, particularly this Christmas with everything that is going on.

The staff will be making donations instead of gifts to each other and we wanted to give the whole community the chance to donate too.

Our retired caretaker, Mr Robinson, has been suffering with cancer for a few years and he has been so well supported by Macmillan Cancer that we wanted to give something back.

Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Mags sadly passed away in hospital after an inoperable tumor was found during surgery in late Sept. She remained amazingly strong and positive right to the end, despite knowing her condition would be terminal and all the complications after surgery that ultimately denied her the opportunity to get home. Macmillan was a charity close to her heart and would have liked friends and family to celebrate her life by giving a donation to them.

Donating through JustGiving is totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
This year Clas 4 are thinking outside the box in how they are going to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support. They have come up with three events, one organised by each class:

  • Whole School Uniform Swap (teachers dressed in uniform and children dressed as teachers)- Friday 27th November
  • Clas 4 Fun Run - Thursday 3rd December
  • Calendar Enterprise Project

We do not expect you to donate to each event separately but would welcome donations of any amount for the first two events and will let you know prices for calendars once we have worked out our costs.

Thank you for your support,

Sgioba C4

pageSummary: I am shaving my hair off because they do amazing work in crazy times
pageSummaryWhat: I am shaving my hair off
pageSummaryWhy: they do amazing work in crazy times
story:
It’s been a difficult time over the past few years with a lot of the family being diagnosed with cancer... it’s felt like a domino effect seeing one after another face the ‘c’ word.  This is for them and to support the amazing work that Macmillan Cancer Support do. 

I’m sure most of you know that Macmillan Cancer Support help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, they’re right right there with you. Amazing!

To raise money, I am going to shave my head... my lovely long locks.... :) 

I will be shaving my hair on Friday 27th November! Wooop!!

I am raising money for 2 charities - thank you so much for your donation.  I would appreciate it if you could split your kind donation between this one and the PWSA (Prader Willi Sydrome) charity. Please check out my other fundraising page! 

https://www.justgiving.com/fundraising/jane-streatfield

Thanks again!

pageSummary: Running walking and biking 150  miles because From December 1st till January 30th
story:
Hi my name is Alfie Gardiner and this is my story on why I’m running 50 miles walking 50 miles and biking 50 miles for Macmillan 

It all started 4 years ago now it was a school morning and I was getting ready to go to school. Just before me and my older sister billie called called upstairs into my bedroom and my mum sat us both on my bed she put her arm around both of us and started getting teary at the point me and billie didn’t know why then we found out why. She told us they my grandad had been diagnosed with prostate cancer. This was devastating but it didn’t make my head drop because I knew my grandad was so strong and I always told myself that. Whenever I met my grandad I didn’t treat him any different because of a disease. Once he had started doing chemotherapy after 2 weeks my grandad was rushed into hospital and this got me becoming really emotional just because I didn’t know what was going to happen and if I would see him. As six months passed and my grandad still in hospital my grandad had to get open heart surgery due to a closing valve connecting to his heart. Soon enough my grandad was allowed back home he would always tell me story’s that he had gained whilst in hopsital and the people around him and what they were like and how they kept him up at night this is because I didn’t see him much whilst in hospital but the odd time I would go on a Friday evening after school my mum would take me and billie and we sat in the hospital room and played dominoes his favourite game and he would always beat me. Now at home I was able to go see him a lot more and I would, he was still going to work at select snacks because he wouldn’t give up and I would go to work with him and after work he would let me grab a drink and a snack as his way of paying me for coming to work with him, I was only able to go to work with I’m on the day I stayed the night round there house which one I did I had a really nice time. My grandad every night for tea when I was there wouldn’t even have to ask me what I would want he knew of the top of his head, his homemade Mac and cheese. The nights I would stay round I would always wake up and go in the living room and see him sat that in his arm chair whatching the news in a button up shirt and jeans at six in the morning !!! Sadly once my grandad had finished chemotherapy he lost all his hair and always wore a hat to cover it up even in his house the only times he would take it of was sleeping and showering. My grandad loved his gardening more then anything other then my Nan. But as time went past he became weaker and struggled to get about but this didn’t make him give up. All in his garden he would have bits and bobs to help him do things a lot easier like when he had chicken to stop him having to go in he would send me in, I’m joking he would have a string to pull to let them in and out and grab the eggs they had layed. Even though he was getting weaker and becoming slower at walking and struggling he would always make time for everyone especially me. There’s one memory that will always stay with me and that’s the time he took me darts at the Addison arms pub in glatton we drove in his blue Ford and went in the back half sat down I got a apple and raspberry j2o and he got himself a cider we got the darts out and played he beat me at another thing. Sooner or later his hair grew back and he took his hat off and this meant a lot as it was a massive step for him that he was able to take . After 2 years having cancer my grandad was still winning and was still being able to do his favourite things like going to the pub and gardening. It’s was 1.5 years ago now and I still remeber this strongly, it was a wet Sunday night my mum and dad had gone to the pub with some friends and I was having a really emotional night to the put were I had enough and I ran out my front doors and into the rain and just sat on the curb my nan and grandad then came and got me and my nan went inside and went to check on everyone as billie was baby sitting but my grandad Ill and in pain came and gave me a hug and stood out in the rain with me. He took me round his house that night and he made us fish fingers and chips and beans and we sat in the conservatory and ate on his circular table and ate he tooked to me about my problems and worry’s and put a smile to my face. As time passed to fast my grandad got worse and was back in hospital and we got told his cancer had spread to his spine and paralysed him. The good news was he didn’t have to stay in hospital and he was able to come home so my Nan got their bedroom re done and able for him to stay in and he had a hospital bed a tv and more stuff in there for his needs. Then lockdown happend causing my family unable to see him but eventually we were able to and it was tuff as he was stuck in bed. During lockdown me and my Nan decided to re do there whole garden as it was over grown and mud from the chickens so we did we spent months on it making it grass and open space. Then it was my grandads 70th birthday my whole family went down and sat in the garden and we were able to get my grandad out in his wheel chair and he was able to see his garden never like it was before and he really liked it we also planted flowers out of the front of there garden so my grandad could look out the window and whatch them grow. Now times got tuff as he was taking turns but he was able to over come them all except one which was horrible my grandads legs were in so much pain and so was he until his nurses decided to put him on medicine that what get rid of all of that pain but the side effect was he just slept all day everyday this lasted for 2 weeks and my mum and auntie speant the last two weeks of his life with him. October the 14th, I came home from school and my uncles car was out the front and I knew something was up as I ran in the door and saw my mum and sister crying and my uncle sat there I knew what had happened I instantly went from smiling to my heart had shattered into a million pieces it was devastating and I had lost my grandad. But I remember all the memories I have with him and that’s massive as I don’t think about what I didn’t do with him I think about what I did with him. 

That’s my story with my grandads battle of cancer for 4 years and I want to give back to Macmillan for helping out so much and I would like to give back a little something so if you could please donate even a pound that would mean so much to me :).

pageSummary: Travelling the distance to the North Pole because the MacMillan Support Line is needed on Xmas Day
pageSummaryWhat: Travelling the distance to the North Pole
pageSummaryWhy: the MacMillan Support Line is needed on Xmas Day
story:
North Pole Challenge

The North Pole is 2,659.95 miles from our Head Office in London, and it costs around £2,500 to fund the MacMillan Support Line on Christmas Day. SSP want to collectively travel the distance to the North Pole by Christmas. You can do this by Running, Cycling, Swimming or Walking.

MacMillan Support Line

The MacMillan Support Line provides easily accessible, free information and support to people with cancer. With a call to just one number, our staff can answer questions about cancer types and treatments, provide practical and financial support, or just listen if someone needs to talk. Especially important this year, while people living with cancer feel more isolated and alone than ever before, a call to someone who will listen could make a big difference. This year for the first time MacMillan will open their support line over the Christmas period including Christmas Day, to make sure we are there for everyone who needs us.

pageSummary: I am going to be taking on a epic cycle challenge because of the support given during such difficult times
pageSummaryWhat: I am going to be taking on a epic cycle challenge
pageSummaryWhy: of the support given during such difficult times
story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support.

Imagine being told you have cancer, the shock, the uncertainty. Imagine you being told you have cancer during Covid-19, isolated, scared, alone. Macmillian has been there for all these people and their families, helping them through each day in such difficult times. 

I heard a story that moved me beyond belief. A widow, due to retire was told they have cancer during the first lockdown. The house they lived in only had part central heating in it. Chemotherapy treatment had started when the central heating fully broke, the costs for a new boiler and system were not affordable to the widow, so they faced spending winter in the cold and fighting the disease. Macmillian stepped in, they fixed the central heating for them to keep them warm. Offered them help and advice during such a difficult time and have been a pillar of strength in someone's desperate time of need.

I could not let this pass me by. I decided to challenge myself in order to support more people like this widow, so I decided to virtually cycle through 6 countries. Am I fit? no. I'm the typical person that pays for a gym membership and never goes. Says I'm going to start running and never do.

This is going to be hard!! but you lovely lot would support me if it was going to be easy!

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Sadly we had to say goodbye to this legend of a man, David (Stave) on 31st October 2020. Due to Covid-19 restrictions he didn't get the send off he deserved. 

We would like everyone to be given the opportunity to pay their last respects by giving support to our chosen charity who provided David and my family with fantastic help and support over the past 11 years. Any donation will be greatly appreciated.

Thanks in advance for your support. 

 


A

story:

Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page in memory of  Norman and contribution to Macmillan Cancer which he supported with such affection.

pageSummary: I am doing this on behalf of my father in law Ken. because My mum in law Irma recently passed away.
pageSummaryWhat: I am doing this on behalf of my father in law Ken.
pageSummaryWhy: My mum in law Irma recently passed away.
story: My beautiful mother inlaw passed away on the 09/11/20. Because of the covid restrictions not everyone will be able to pay their respects at her funeral. This is so sad as she is a brave strong  incredibly funny woman who deserved so much more. On behalf of my father inlaw and all our family we do not want flowers sent for the funeral and would perfer you to donate to the Macmillan charity instead if you so wish too.  They do a sterling job in looking after people through their darkest hours and in the time of need. I want to thank everyone who have already sent messages, cards, flowers and tributes. Irma,s funeral is on the 27/11/20 a link will be sent to anyone who would like to pay their respects on the day.  Thank you again Xxx

story: This year we are raising money for Macmillan in memory of my mums beautiful youngest sister Kerry Woodbury  An incredible wife, mum, daughter, sister, auntie and friend. She was loved by so many and battled for so long before she was very cruelly taken from us on 03/09/2020 - a day we will never forget. This year we have already raised a substantial amount of money, but what's a little more? Macmillan were incredible and looked after her throughout the last few months of her life and we would love to raise some money for them. If you can donate anything at all, please do❤❤

Please donate today to help make sure we can keep delivering all our critical services.
charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Throughout the month of December I will be running a full marathon (26 miles) in an attempt to raise money for Macmillan Cancer Support. Macmillan are a truly amazing charity that provides specialist health care, information and financial support to people and families affected by cancer. Macmillan take the time to understand you as a person, so that they can provide the support, tools and inspiration you need to find your best way through. 

On two separate occasions my mum has been diagnosed with cancer; bowel cancer and breast cancer. Hearing the 'c' word was one of the most scary and soul destroying experiences we as a family have witnessed. Thankfully, through the medical care of the NHS and support of Macmillan we rose above this both times and kicked cancer out. Along this journey Macmillan were there to offer an array of support packages to make this journey that slight bit easier. Words cannot describe how thankful we are for a charity like this. At some point in life everyone is affected by cancer, and Macmillan are there to hold your hand through it all 💚

pageSummary: I am running 76 miles before Xmas because they supported our family when we most needed it.
pageSummaryWhat: I am running 76 miles before Xmas
pageSummaryWhy: they supported our family when we most needed it.
story:
My dad sadly lost his 2 1/2 year battle with cancer on 06 November 2020. He was a proud, hard working family man who I loved and respected very much. On hearing the terrible news that treatment would no longer be effective his only wish was to be at home with his family for his final weeks. Macmillan Cancer Support provided us (particularly my lovely step-mum Julia White) with advice and guidance. Without their compassion and support, dad would have needed to enter a care home and would have passed alone (Covid-19 restrictions!). Although we are all heartbroken he is no longer with us, we are very grateful that Macmillan nurses made it possible for us to be there when he needed us most .

Until his diagnosis of cancer Dad had always been healthy and we expected to be able to share many more great years together. Unfortunately he was only 76 years old when he died and I wish to mark this number by running 76 miles before Christmas. I will start my challenge on 23 November and hope my weary legs will keep me strong throughout

I kindly request your support in my challenge by making a donation to Macmillan Cancer Support via my justgiving page.

Thank you very much.
title: David's 76 Mile Challenge

pageSummary: Running an endurance event every month till I am40 because They supported my family as well so many others.
pageSummaryWhat: Running an endurance event every month till I am40
pageSummaryWhy: They supported my family as well so many others.
story:
As well as many of you, I have been personally struck by the life changing effects Cancer has on your life. In 2003 my Mum passed away from a very short fight from Bowel cancer. Unfortunately history repeated its self in 2016 when my husbands Father lost his very short battle from Pancreatic Cancer. Then when a close friend of my sons family where hit by this awful disease I wanted to do something to really bring notice to this horrible disease and push myself that little bit further. I began running and each race I ran a little bit further. I realised could do something epic in my little life of being a Mummy - Run an Ultra every month till September 2021 when I will be 40. However this year has not gone to plan and my Ultra events have been turned into slightly different virtual endurance events. 

Throughout this year I have had to overcome my own obstacles, coping with asthma and hay fever allergies and juggling working along with 2 very active boys but with the support of my amazing family and friends I have been able to chip away at this challenge.  

Thanks for supporting my fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, we’re right right there with you.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
eventName: Shanghai to London BD Step Challenge
story:
The Shanghai to London BD step challenge has been set-up to honour our colleague Nick’s positive outlook whilst undergoing treatment for cancer. As a team, we aim to collectively walk/run/hike a total distance of 5,711 miles ove the next two months which equates to 11,422,000 steps to reach London from Shanghai.

As an individual, we aim to walk 10,000 steps a day, however there will be days where this is not possible so we need to work as a team to reach our target.

Please can we ask you to make a donation in support of our team challenge :)

Team Members below:

Nick Rose, Guy Gregory, James McLean, Cherrelle King, Lisa Commins, Lauren Blackwell, Bobbie Harris, Ben Hymans, Tom Lewis, Fiona Joyce, Yasmin Dubash, Sue Clayton, Monique Lopez, Owen Morgan, Charles Jorcin, Patrick Brown, Katherine Suker, Nina Shaw, Anthony Woodward, Nick Wright, Mike Landolt, Kasia Dziewulska

pageSummary: We are raising money in memory of Joe because of their amazing care
pageSummaryWhat: We are raising money in memory of Joe
story:
Joe Cordina, beloved husband of our friend Mary, father of Danielle, grandfather of Mylo.

When Joe smiled, his whole face smiled and that was never more the case than when he was with his family and particularly Mylo, his darling grandson. 

Joe passed away on 12th November, surrounded by his family who were everything to him. Our love and strength are with them all.

Funeral service to be held at Wessex Vale Crematorium on Monday 30th November 2020 at 2:30 pm

Due to the current situation, attendance will be by invitation only.

If you wish to attend the service remotely, please use the following link:

Websitehttps://www.obitus.com/
UsernameSuxo6746
Password906892

Once you have accessed the webpage, you will find the login boxes on the top right of your screen.

Wessex Vale Crematorium, Bubb Lane, West End, Southampton SO30 2HL

pageSummary: I am cycling 100km in chilly, wet & windy November because my brother-in-law has been diagnosed with cancer.
pageSummaryWhat: I am cycling 100km in chilly, wet & windy November
pageSummaryWhy: my brother-in-law has been diagnosed with cancer.
story:
After a 2 year break, I have agreed to take part in the virtual Barclays Wheels For Change event that will involve me cycling 100km in chilly, wet and windy November in aid of a good cause. As it is a virtual event, we have been able to select charities close to us.

I have decided to raise money for MacMillan Cancer Support. Unfortunately, earlier this year my brother-in-law was diagnosed with cancer. He is now undergoing treatment which is extremely tough both mentally and physically but he has found the support provided by MacMillan amazing. They are there to support him anytime of day with whatever concerns the cancer throws at him.

If you can make a donation that would be greatly appreciated as it will help the many people diagnosed with cancer every year.

Take Care and remember if you feel something isn’t right get it checked out. It is most likely nothing, but if it is detected early this should assist with any treatment required.

Rob

Thanks for supporting my fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, we’re right right there with you. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

story:
To cheer everyone up and help a fab charity, I’ll be posting a photo each day of Stanley with/at a place beginning with each letter of the alphabet 😊

I’ve known too many folk affected by cancer to specify individuals however this fundraiser is dedicated to ALL of them - survivors 💪🏼, currently fighting 🤞🏼, or no longer with us 💔.

Charities have had a really bad year with so much fundraising having to be cancelled, so let’s do what we can 😊

story:
With everything going on with the virus, we have not be able to fundraise like we normally do and I wanted to do something to lift everybody sprites. I will wear different jumpers each week including at work (My boss has ok'd this) as well as on Xmas week I be wearing a reindeer onesie (though I may still wear a jumper if its's cold enough).

Photos will be posted on here, my Facebook and my Twitter pages. It starts on the 1st and ends the 31st.

pageSummaryWhat: Donate for walking  a marathon in a month
pageSummaryWhy: we were unable to hold our annual coffee morning.
story:
Thanks for supporting our fundraising. Macmillan cancer support is a charity close to all our hearts so we are challenging ourselves to stay fit and healthy in these difficult times, by walking/ running/ riding a marathon in one month! At 2 miles a day I, for one, intend to complete 60 miles!!

Join in the challenge and get your friends involved, how many miles can we manage together?

Sponsor for miles or just donate,  anything you can do to support this great charity!!

Let me know how many miles you walk each week and I will update our total.

  Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
As we are getting closer to Christmas, things have never felt so busy. I thought we could take some time out to have a little bit of fun to lighten peoples spirit. Lockdowns, face masks and isolating has felt like such a burden but as a team we have been stronger than ever. 

With the recent news that my cancer has returned. I'm hoping we can raise a bit of money to Macmillan, their support has been incredible with my first diagnosis and they continue to provide such amazing support to those affected by cancer.

Get those Christmas Jumpers at the ready!

pageSummary: I'm donating my 50th Birthday Gifts to Charity because They supported my mum during her last few months
pageSummaryWhat: I'm donating my 50th Birthday Gifts to Charity
pageSummaryWhy: They supported my mum during her last few months
story:
My mother Gwenda Hucks died a few weeks short of her 50th birthday due to cancer.  In those last few months of her life Macmillan Nurses helped support not only my mum but also my father at a very difficult time.  As I'm about to turn 50 myself and given the current climate I've decided to ask everyone to donate to Macmillan instead of buying me a gift.  Let's face it I can only spend so much money on golf lol.

So if you can spare a few quid I would be exceptionally grateful. 

Thanks for supporting my fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. charity.description: Macmillan nurses, doctors and health professionals will continue to support people living with cancer whilst doing all they can to help alleviate the immense strain put on the NHS by coronavirus. Please donate today to help make sure we can keep delivering all our critical services.
charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
In recent years I have suffered tremendous losses of close family relatives to this disease. Immense pain is caused by the loss of your loved ones and little comfort can be found to heal the wounds. 

I would like to contribute in supporting the great work that Macmillan are doing in assisting cancer sufferers across the world. With this in mind, I've decided to combine my passion for fitness in supporting Macmillan's great cause. I will run a 10K race everyday for 10 days on the 7th December - 17th December and look for your support. 

Let us do this as a team and raise funding to help make a difference in the future of people's lives, and do everything we can to support eliminating this disease. 

Thank you.

charity.description: Macmillan nurses, doctors and health professionals will continue to support people living with cancer whilst doing all they can to help alleviate the immense strain put on the NHS by coronavirus. Please donate today to help make sure we can keep delivering all our critical services.
charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Last December (the day before my 21st birthday, to be exact) I had to have a major emergency operation to remove an ovarian tumour. It was only once they'd removed the tumour that they discovered it was cancerous and could have ruptured at any moment, spreading the cancer throughout my entire body. I am so so thankful to God for miraculously providing the emergency operation slot, as well as for the doctors, hospital staff and of course, my Macmillan team. Throughout the pre-op appointments, recovery process & beyond, my Macmillan nurses and carers have been a huge blessing & support to me and my family. So for my birthday this year, I want to give back to Macmillan and help them in their support of other cancer patients.

Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, we’re right right there with you. Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

pageSummary: We're hosting a virtual Christmas Jumper Day because every year we raise money for this amazing charity
pageSummaryWhat: We're hosting a virtual Christmas Jumper Day
pageSummaryWhy: every year we raise money for this amazing charity
story:
Every year Reconomy, together with some of our wider Group brands, raises money for Macmillan Cancer Support via their amazing annual coffee morning. Sadly with our offices currently closed due to the pandemic we’ve not been able to host this hugely popular event this year.

Macmillan Cancer Support is too close to all our hearts to simply do nothing, so we’ve decided to hold a ‘Virtual Christmas Jumper Day’ this year on Friday 11th December 2020.

To get involved, simply wear your favourite Christmas Jumper for work on Friday 11th December and make a donation of at least £1 to Macmillan Cancer Support by clicking GIVE NOW.

Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support.  Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, we’re right right there with you.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

Abigail - I want you show support for my Nana Vi in Wales who has had a horrible time in and out of hospital and going through chemo therapy. I can’t get to see her right now so I wanted to show her she’s not alone in losing her hair by donating mine to the Little Princess Trust for children who suffer from cancer. I am raising money for Macmillan as the nurses have already supported my nana and they are so important to so many people suffering from cancer.  I’d really appreciate any donation no matter how big or small, thank you 💚

charity.description: Macmillan nurses, doctors and health professionals will continue to support people living with cancer whilst doing all they can to help alleviate the immense strain put on the NHS by coronavirus. Please donate today to help make sure we can keep delivering all our critical services.
charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Like a lot of people, i have witnessed the sadness that cancer can cause. I lost not only a grandma, but genuinely my best friend to this disease, at an age that i could'nt really comprehend it. Cancer, if it has not already will affect most of us in our lives. It is devastating for both the sufferer and their family. Research and funding is really making a difference, and if we can support that further and tell cancer to fuck off, then i am more than happy to be a part of it. Cancer has come back to affect people i know and love since then, but most have give it the middle finger and beat it. For all of you, i want to help. And this is my way of doing it. Please sponsor not just me, but the whole brigade that is building against this horrible bastard. I just want to make it clear that this distance is way out of my league, and won't hit it. I am unable to change the distance, but I will try my best to get as close as i can and do as much as possible. I start on the 7th December officially but will probably start sooner. Thank you friends xxx

Mary Rita Satchell October 2001 xxx

pageSummary: I’ll be running 5k for 10 consecutive days because I want to do my bit for this incredible charity
pageSummaryWhat: I’ll be running 5k for 10 consecutive days
pageSummaryWhy: I want to do my bit for this incredible charity
story:
Sadly, cancer is a disease that will impact all of us at some stage of our lives, whether directly or indirectly. 

This is my small contribution to the phenomenal work done by the fantastic Macmillan team. I appreciate these are tough times for so many people, but any contribution you can make towards this fantastic cause will be very much appreciated. 

£29 can pay for a Macmillan nurse for an hour, helping people living with cancer and their families receive essential medical, practical and emotional support. I’ve set myself a fundraising target of £696 to cover the cost of a Macmillan nurse for 24 hours. 

Please help me to reach the magic number.

Thank you so much for your support.!

story: Ok, so I’m going for the Game Hero Challenge! 24 hours non stop gaming for Macmillan! My own father passed away from cancer 14 years ago this Christmas and any Cancer charity has my support! What better way to raise money than by doing something you enjoy, however 24 hours is pushing the limit! I’m looking to do 24 hours of non-stop Elder Scrolls- Skyrim on Xbox One starting 09:00 on 28/12/20 and ending at 09:00 the next day breaking only for bathroom breaks and food breaks. Regular updates will be on my Facebook page on the day including posts about my my own sanity! I aim to raise £500 but anything around that would be an achievement!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

story: Hi all. I was diagnosed with Terminal Lung Cancer on the 13/09/2013. I was given a diagnosis of six weeks to a year. My mother Denise Young was already having treatment for breast cancer at the time. On the 20th of September 2013 my Father in Law was also diagnosed with bowel cancer and passed away 13/11/2013. During this super hard period of mine and my family life the guys at McMillan where super hero's. They gave us support, help with sorting out all the little things like getting me on benefits and disability payments. These little things may not seem like much but they made the world of difference back then. I now foster and the kids and I would like to raise some money for this great charity, so we will be doing a 24 hours gaming session.

story:
Hi 💚

Firstly, thank you for looking at my fundraiser!

I will be walking 5km everyday for 10 days (Starting tomorrow 23rd November) in the hope to not only raise money for a brilliant cause, but to also improve my fitness.

I understand funds may be a little low due to the pandemic and Christmas being around the corner, but even if you can spare just £1 it would be greatly appreciated and will be going towards a brilliant cause!

I understand the pain we unfortunately have to face when we loose a loved one to cancer 😔 hence why I want to push myself to do this to try help raise money for those who need the support from Macmillan.

Thank you in advance to anyone who donates and anyone who shares my post!

Charlotte xXx 💚

pageSummary: 26 mile hike from Dartmoor to Bakewell! because It’s a personal charity close to me
pageSummaryWhat: 26 mile hike from Dartmoor to Bakewell!
pageSummaryWhy: It’s a personal charity close to me
story:
Cancer isnt going anywhere, and Macmillan are working tirelessly to ensure people with cancer are getting the vital support they need right now; more than ever. But they cant do it alone and need our support. 

By donating to my hiking challenge, youll get me one step closer to my fundraising target so that Macmillan can create new services, adapt old ones and speak up on behalf of people living with cancer. A lot more people deal with Cancer than you know and it’s a charity very close to my heart! However big or small all donations are appreciated! Thankyou everyone! ❤️

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story: My name is Abby Wilkinson I'm 30 years old and I have been battling Small Cell Cervical Cancer since January 2020. After months and months of gruelling treatment I am truely in awe of what these people do for us cancer sufferers and their families, and they need all the money we can give them. As they say.. 'When someone has cancer, their whole family and everyone who loves them does too". My end of treatment scans are quickly approaching, so I have chosen this moment to challenge myself and not let the cancer take control and tell me what I can or can't do. Please support me and help me raise as much money as possible for Macmillan to help others living with cancer.
title: Cancer may have started the fight, but I will finish it
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Highlight: ...Cancer may have started the fight, but I will finish...

story: I have been playing World of Warcraft for 12 years now and I love the game. My mum and dad introduced me to the game we all loved playing it. 4 years ago my mum sadly passed away from cancer so for a long time now I have always wanted to raise money for Macmillan. They were very supportive of me and my family and most importantly my mum when she was passing on. So how could I raise money? well, there were several ways but I felt the best way was doing something I loved and my mum loved and that was playing world of warcraft.

story:
I am challenging myself big time here but hope to raise much needed funds for a charity close to my family.

I was diagnosed with psoriatic arthritis over 5 years ago which is mainly in my feet.  I started drinking ketones just over 6 months ago and they have totally transformed my life for the better.
I sadly lost my mum to cancer and my dad was diagnosed with cancer but thankfully after treatment and a major operation he is now cancer free.
Macmillan have been a great help and I have seen first hand all the good work they do and would like to help a little bit.

story: As many of you already know, I lost my beautiful mum in 2010 to ovarian cancer. I can't quite believe I haven't had a mum for 10 years now, that's a quarter of my life so far without my kindred spirit. 10 years on.... And it sometimes feels like it was all just a dream having a mum. Life can be cruel but somehow we have to carry on and just keep running. So that's what I plan to do with the rest of LD2.

if you can spare as little as £1 you can help a family get the support they need

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising.  Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, we’re right right there with you.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

story: When I was 9 my dad was diagnosed with skin cancer in his nose after being badly sunburnt on holiday, he then had a bit of his nose removed and the cancer was gone. I am doing this to raise money and awareness for my dad and other people and their families that are experiencing or experienced the same. Thank you :)

pageSummary: We will be running 50k over 10 days!
pageSummaryWhat: We will be running 50k over 10 days!
story:
Abby and I have decided to attempt to take part in Macmillan’s 10 day 5k challenge! We will be running 5k a day over 10 consecutive days, 50k in total. We have literally only just started running as a hobby, the furthest we’ve ran so far is 4k. But we’re up to this challenge to raise money for this amazing charity. We understand times are hard and money is tight just before Christmas, but if you could spare just a little we would be so grateful!😊

Thanks for supporting my fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, we’re right right there with you.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

story:
At 5am on Saturday 21st of November 2020 I am raising money for Cancer Research by joining a 24hr gaming challenge.  Every step we make towards beating cancer relies on every pound donated to fund the diagnosis and treatment of cancer and saves millions of lives. Over the past 40 years survival has doubled, thanks to the great progress research has made. Did you know £100 will pay for an urgent biopsy and £50 will buy specialised lab equipment for early diagnosis.

If you are unable to donate please share my link.

Thanks

Charlie

story: Hi all and thanks for looking. Myself and my twin are looking to raise £100 for Macmillan. We have recently discovered that our grandma who we are close to and looked after us for some time while our parents went abroad had been diagnosed with stage 4 cancer. After this devastating news we thought this would be a good way to mix a great deed with something we love to do which is game. We appreciate any help and support and any donations as little as £1 go a long way. A massive thank you in advance and hope you guys support us in this 24hr stream! Thank you.

story:
So to mark another journey around the sun, I'm going to marathon my way through Borderlands 3 and raise some funds for MacMillan. 

Starting at 8pm on Thursday, the plan is to play through to 8pm on Friday, finish up the charity stream and go into a celebratory session of Among Us!

I'd love to raise £5 per hour averaged over the 24 hour stream, so £120 total. If I raise less than this, I'll make up the difference.
If you can support in any way, it would be much appreciated. Whether that be a donation or popping in to chat to keep me going! 

Let's do this!

story: Aimee & I will be running 5k for the next 10 days to raise funds for Macmillan Cancer support.  It was the wish of our dear friend Denise that we support Macmillan on her behalf.  Sadly Denise only had a short 12 months after her cancer diagnosis, but she was brave and upbeat and remained positive throughout her illness despite everything she had to endure. She will be greatly missed by all her friends.  Our 10th run will fall on what would have been Denise’s 52nd Birthday, which we feel will be a fitting way to mark this day.  We will definitely be doing the “Denise Dash” 🏃🏻‍♀️❤️ By donating to our challenge you can help to ensure that people whose lives are affected by cancer get the vital support that they need.  Please support us in anyway that you can, no donation is too small.  Xx
title: 5k for 10 days in Memory of our lovely friend Denise

story:
Hi everyone,
On Wednesday next week (25th) I will be completing a 24 hour livestream of various games to raise money for MacMillan cancer support starting at 12pm.

To get to my JustGiving page follow the donate button on this page! Remember every little helps! My Twitch account is below, feel free to join the stream and give support throughout, streaming for 24 hours straight is not going to be easy, so come egg me on and feel free to drop me a follow so you don't miss the stream! 

https://www.twitch.tv/willlovell98 

With everything else going on in the world its good to share so positivity, so if you do come to join the stream, please keep things kind and supportive or I'll put you on the naughty step 😉

story:
In 2016 I lost my step dad to a brain tumour, which personally effected me very hard and to this day still does. Fast forward 4 and a half years and now my mum is fighting ovarian cancer, she’s currently undergoing chemo and has surgery scheduled for early 2021. I know my mums a fighter and will win. 
I came across “game hero’s” and having streamed before I decided to sign up. I’m mainly going to stream fortnite game play with my son anthony who’s 9, friends and family.  Any donations are greatly appreciated and any one who wants to join in can do. Please follow my twitch account as I’ll be doing a few test streams between now and the 2nd January 2021 to make sure everything runs smoothly on the day.

story:
Cancer lays a close place in my heart as seeing my sister suffer from breast cancer for years and survive it, and years later losing one of my best friends to testicular cancer. It’s time to come together and beat this! The prevalence rate for cancer in 2019 was well over 100,000 and this is set to double in the next decade. Cancer has affected all of of us in one way or another if isn’t a family member or a friend we all know someone affected by cancer. I would like to raise a small amount of money to help Macmillan by doing something I love which is gaming. So please help me to achieve the £500 mark!
Let’s do this!!!

story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising.  Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, we’re right right there with you.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story: So all my life I’ve been surrounded by cancer. My Nan overcame it. My grandad has it still. He’s fighting hard to overcome this. My nan really inspires me to keep fighting because even though she was held down by such a deadly disease, she was able to overcome it and is extremely active to this day. My grandad also inspires me, he does radiotherapy everyday, and he’s still able to keep a smile on his face and talk to me and be his funny usual self. My other grandad who I call Vapa overcame prostate cancer and he makes me proud everyday. I want to help others to overcome what my grandparents have gone/going through.

Your support will be much appreciated.

By donating to my challenge you can help to ensure that people with cancer get the vital support they need right now and help stop cancer from becoming the forgotten 'C'. On a personal note it has been an incredibly tough year for many of us due to an unknown virus which turned into a pandemic and the pernicious impacts it has created physically and mentally. In the run up to the end of "2020" I thought to sign myself up for this wonderful cause and create a positive impact on the community. My 10 day 5k challenge starts on Nov 23rd. I'll give my best to reach the finishing line by jogging, walking, creeping or crawling. Hope you can support & cheer me up by making any donations you can. I'll be updating my daily progress here.

pageSummaryWhat: I am taking part in the Macmillan Mystery Knit
pageSummaryWhy: I would like to support people affected by cancer
story: During these difficult times charities need our support more than ever. I am asking for donations to Macmillan and it is a cause very close to my heart. My Macmillan Cancer Nurse was so important to us as a family when I received my diagnosis in 2013. I want to ensure that others affected will continue to receive the exceptional care that we were fortunate to have. . Thanks for supporting my fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, we’re right right there with you.Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
At the beginning of this year I could barely be bothered to walk 5 minutes, let alone RUN 5k. The first lockdown gave me the time to work on my fitness and achieve my goal, and I would be running 5k a day for 2 weeks straight out of pure boredom! This time round the weather isn't as bright and beautiful, I'm back to work and also can't remember the last time I actually ran 5k. So starting from Monday 30 November, I will be running 5k every day for 10 days for Macmillan Cancer Support.

Cancer has affected so many people close to me so this is the perfect time and opportunity to do something for them. By donating to my challenge you can help to ensure that people with cancer get the vital support they need right now and help stop cancer from becoming the forgotten 'C'.

story: Hello wonderful people, as a lot of you know, 2020 hasn't been kind to many of us and, even though the pandemic continues, cancer still adds to the destructive force of 2020. I know people close to me that have lost someone dear to them, I know people who are suffering from cancer. I can't really do much scientifically but there is one thing that I can do and that's play video games for a VERY long time. I've wanted to do something for a cancer charity for a long time and now this is a good opportunity for me to raise some money for a good cause AND have fun whilst doing it. I will post on Tik Tok, Insta and Snapchat making an announcement for this event and will be live streaming on twitch! Come watch and, if possible, make a donation or share with your friends and family and get the word out. It'll be for a good cause and I know it'll be a good laugh.

story:
Living with cancer as we all know can be seriously tedious and immensly unfortunate, So we are here today to make people aware of the seriousness of the the disease, it may be called cancer, but it comes in all sizes and places in the human body.
So please step and donate generously to the cause, as scientists, researchers, and crew of Macmillan to do their magnificant work to support people affected by cancer.

My name is Monty, am originally from Iraq live in Scotland, 33 and a half years old :P am not quite enjoying gaming as much as I used to, however, for this cause, am willing to do it for twenty four hours, playing different games across my steam library. let's see how we get on.

story:
Gonna try playing videogames for 24 hours straight to raise money for McMillan on the 23rd to the 24th of November. For 2 reasons: 
1) I'm very lazy and running for charity or whatever isn't my thing. 
2) The big one, McMillan is a very important charity to me. As many of you will know my dad lost his battle with lung cancer last year. Along with the Rowan's Hospice, McMillan in particular were of enormous support to me and my family during quite frankly the worst time of my life. 
So please go to the link below if you would like to make a donation. I've set a small target that I hope I will be able to meet, and you can pop into chat to either give me a message of support or call me a dickhead or whatever, up to you really.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
Thanks for supporting my fundraising. Macmillan Cancer Support is here to help everyone with cancer live life as fully as they can, providing physical, financial and emotional support. So whatever cancer throws your way, we’re right right there with you.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs.

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story: Cancer will affect 1 in 2 people in their lifetime. The UK has a higher cancer rate than 90% of the world. Every two minutes a person in the UK is diagnosed with cancer. 4 out of every 10 cancer cases are preventable. Macmillan Cancer Support strives to reach and improve everyone affected by cancer's lives. Their mission is not over help them by donating towards this great cause. We will be streaming a 24 hour live stream through twitch from 8am GMT on 19th December till 8am GMT on 20th December. Any donation will help no matter how large or small, even spreading the word will help us to achieve our goal.

story: From  the 7th of December I am going to try and raise some money for Macmillan Cancer Support to help support them with the amazing work they do. I am going to run 5K a day for 10 consecutive days. For some this is not an amazing achievement but for me at 14st, 11lb this will test me and hopefully I will loose some weight in the process, and reduce my risk of certain cancers, so it's win, win really as long as I don't have a heart attack.

pageSummary: Running because 2020 Edinburgh Half Marathon Virtual Challenge
story: Welcome to my Just Giving fundraising page! I am running this half marathon virtual event for Macmillan Cancer Support. I am not a runner (can barely run 5k..) so I will be doing this over 3 days in the week commencing 21st December. Unfortunately due to Covid-19 and lockdown the income of charities have been reduced so it is a good time to show your support! Macmillan Cancer Support is a fantastic Charity and I would be so grateful if you could take the time to sponsor me to help the cause and to motivate me in my training!

charity.name: Macmillan Cancer Support
story:
4 years ago we lost my mum to lung cancer which had spread to her bones. She got sick very quickly, diagnosed 10th October and she passed 20th December. We needed a lot of help and support, emotionally and practically especially because of the speed at which she deteriorated. Macmillan was there from the first time mum was diagnosed to introducing us to support groups, helping with treatments & the 100's of worries and questions we had, providing equipment for home and even getting a stair lift installed for us. When the end came they helped us find mum a hospice and was at the end of the phone with help and support. 


Please help me give a little back by supporting this crazy idea to run 5km every day for 10 days!

story: On Monday 23rd I will be starting day 1 of my 10 day challenge to complete 3 miles a day. Since having a baby 4 months ago I’ve really enjoyed getting back into my fitness. This will be a challenge not only to get out the house without 3 children in tow but to have to do it for 10 days in a row. I never really thought about cancer affecting our family until my uncle was diagnosed with it a few years ago and sadly past away from it. And now my beautiful cousin is currently going through chemo to beat it! She’s  an incredibly brave woman and I admire how positive she is. Times are tough at the minute so I ask you all, no matter how big or small to please donate as I take on this challenge for a brilliant charity. Thanks Amy xx

story: Although you see many fundraisers throughout the year, I try and complete at least once a year for something close to home.  Macmillan is my chosen charity this year. Last year we lost Steph's grandad on the 29th June 2019 after his fight with Cancer. He had back problems for a long time and after many X-Rays and scans, in June 2018 he was diagnosed with terminal liver cancer which has spread to his spine. With the time we had with him, you truely understand the devastating trail Cancer leaves on loved ones, family and friends and the hole that remains after someone passes away.  If I can raise just a little bit to help another family deal with Cancer throughout recovery or illness by having support then I can make 2020 a little more positive.  Ive decided to make it a little more challenging as the weather is cold, wet and windy throughout December. I will be starting the challenge on 7th December 2020 and will be doing a 5K run for 10 consecutive days.
title: 5km Run Per Day For 10 Consecutive Days - In Memory Of Thomas Shaw

story:
Hello! Thanks for viewing our page. We are three good friends with a passion for gaming and a hole in each of our hearts from a loss due to cancer. While 24 hours of non stop gaming sounds amazing, we've all been affected by this devastating disease and are more than happy to jump at the chance to help in any way we can.

Please donate, not just for us and our losses, but for the losses felt around the world. Feel free to watch us as we livestream our session, and share our link with your friends and family!

Mikki, Demi & Grace.

story: I have only just started getting into walking large distances, I used to hate walking but since lockdown I decided to change my attitude and I am amazed by how far I can walk. The furthest I have done in one go is 10.5miles. My feet hurt after but it just makes me want to keep going. Hoping that after this my feet don't actually fall off. I want to raise money for Macmillan because Cancer is a horrible disease that has killed far to many people I know. My nanny had breast cancer and thankfully she recovered but I can't imagine the hell she had to go through to get better. Macmillian help so many people and so I want to do this so they can keep helping more people to the best of their ability.

charity.name: St John Ambulance
pageSummary: Raising money to fight the battle against Covid-19 because St John volunteers directly support the NHS
pageSummaryWhat: Raising money to fight the battle against Covid-19
pageSummaryWhy: St John volunteers directly support the NHS
story:
Having joined St John in January 2020 as a member of the Oxfordshire Priory Group to help in both fundraising and representing the charity, I was just getting to know the team when the Covid-19 pandemic hit the UK. It has been truly remarkable to see the support St John has provided the NHS so far and how quickly that support was generated.

In the fight against coronavirus St John Ambulance volunteers are on the frontline, standing alongside our brave NHS. St John urgently need funds to put more first aiders and ambulance crews into communities up and down the country.

St John Ambulance saves lives every day and as we face the extraordinary demands of this ongoing health emergency resources are stretched like never before and we need your support right now.  With your help we will continue to support communities after the crisis by training young people and adults to learn lifesaving first aid including the right preparation to ensure our volunteers can help the nation in emergencies whenever they need us. St John also need to keep its fleet on the road and Ambulances need to be replaced and upgraded, this is where you can really help and where my bid to run the next London Marathon will hopefully make a difference.

There has been a long family association with St John with both my Grandfather Jack Petersen, a great boxer in his day, and my father John. It seemed only right for me to try to follow in their footsteps, quite literally in this case!  

Plans to run the 2020 London Marathon for St John changed somewhat as a result of Covid-19 with the vast majority of runners taking part in a 'virtual event'.  I too took to the streets on a dark, wet and miserable Sunday afternoon to complete the 26.2 miles around the streets of Newbury, sadly without the crowds and atmosphere to distract me from the rain, wind and rather sore feet.  Proudly wearing my St John vest as I made my way around the course it was heartening to see and hear so many people stop, wave, clap and honk their horns in support, thank you one and all!

Many of you have kindly offered to support me having successfully completed the 2020 virtual event, but now we switch focus to 2021 Marathon and the real fundraising effort begins.  This time, fingers crossed, I will again take to the streets of London, and with the weight of support of the Oxfordshire Priory Group behind me, we hope to raise as much as we can to support the St John emergency campaign.  Raising £10,000 would make a huge difference in the campaign but just imagine if we could raise a whopping £104,000, the cost of a brand new Ambulance! Oh yes, and at the same time, I really must beat my rather modest PB of 5 Hrs 11 minutes, surely 5th time lucky!

You no doubt would want to know what impact your donation might make, so here are some examples outlining what specific donation amounts could help fund:

£100 could help us urgently up-skill and train volunteers.

Your support could help our many volunteers who need additional training in order to work safely with patients in ambulances, hospitals and in communities during this national emergency. You could also help us to train new volunteers and fast-track them through tailored training courses and continue this work long term.

£500 could support our volunteer operations to make sure they can respond quickly.

In this urgent crisis your support could be the difference between a life lost and a life saved. With your help we can make sure our volunteers and staff are connected at all times and are able to respond quickly to a fast-moving situation.

£1,000+ will support the future of St John Ambulance’s work through COVID-19 and beyond.

Our role in communities and across the country has never been more vital and with your help we will save lives. Your support will enable us to continue to be the nation’s leading community health and first aid charity.

£104,000+ will pay for the delivery of a brand new Ambulance to help support St John Ambulance’s work through COVID-19 and beyond.

St John and COVID-19

The number of coronavirus cases and deaths in the country continues to rise with significant impact on and stretching of NHS resources. During the COVID-19 outbreak, St John is actively supporting ambulance services, hospitals and communities to protect life and health through this worrying and uncertain period.

“St John Ambulance is facing extraordinary demands, the likes of which our organisation has not faced in peacetime. Our charity’s resources are being stretched, and our people are being tested, but we will stop at nothing to help beat this virus.” Richard Lee, Chief Operating Officer and COVID Strategic Commander

Right now, St John is stepping forward to save lives, with thousands of fully trained volunteers. We are supporting the NHS to care for people during the COVID-19 pandemic. Our charity’s vital role responding to the needs of communities across the nation has never been more relevant or urgent.

St John volunteers are supporting patients right now in the NHS Nightingale Hospital in London, and in hospital emergency departments up and down the country caring for those in need. As more Nightingale hospitals open our volunteers stand ready to do more. Our volunteer ambulance crews are also working 24/7 supporting 999 call outs and transporting recovered patients back home safely.

So please dig deep, spread the word and let’s do all we can to smash the initial £10,000 target and who knows, perhaps we might even get to the magic £104,000 dream goal! Thank you for anything you can spare and I promise to pull my finger out and make sure my marathon time starts with a 4...!!

A huge thank you for all your help,

Matt

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story: Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

pageSummary: In memory of my amazing Grandad Ken and because Grandad sadly passed away from a heart attack
pageSummaryWhat: In memory of my amazing Grandad Ken and
pageSummaryWhy: Grandad sadly passed away from a heart attack
story:
As most of you know my Grandad suddenly and sadly passed away in July after suffering a massive heart attack. 

I haven't done any exercise in over 12 months so this is a kick up the backside to get myself active again and to raise so money for a good cause that is close to my heart. 

My Grandad was my hero and my first best friend, I wanted to do something in this memory and this 100km run in 30 days will finish on what would have been his 78th birthday on the 23rd December.  

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. 

£24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support.

story:
In December, my school is taking part in the British Heart Foundation’s Christmas fundraising initiative, ‘The BHF Elf Kick’!

Elf Kick is a series of 12 christmas themed fitness and wellbeing challenges that the school will take part in, over 12 consecutive days in December. 

Where does the fundraising come in?

By raising money I can help the BHF to fund more machines that can restart hearts, it would give them the ability to fix arteries in tiny babies and the power to give someone a heart they weren’t born with!

Please get involved to support a fantastic charity!

pageSummary: TSA pupils are taking part in the BHF Elf Kick because it is a charity close to our hearts
pageSummaryWhat: TSA pupils are taking part in the BHF Elf Kick
pageSummaryWhy: it is a charity close to our hearts
story:
The Skipton Academy are collecting vital funds for the British Heart Foundation, to power pioneering research into heart and cardiovascular diseases. This is a charity close to our hearts after former Head of Science, Catherine White, died following heart surgery in 2015. Since then, TSA have raised money for the British Heart Foundation including installing a defibrillator and completed Restart a Heart training within lessons.  

This December pupils will be taking part in the BHF Elf Kick. 

There has never been a more important time for children to get
moving and focus on their health and wellbeing. 2020 has been a very difficult year for pupils and school staff so the British Heart Foundation (BHF) have created a brand new initiative that will allow children to get ‘fit and elfy’ this Christmas, have some festive fun in a completely Covid friendly way and all whilst raising funds for the BHF’s lifesaving research.

What is the BHF Elf Kick? Elf Kick is a series of 12 fitness and wellbeing challenges that the school will take part in, over 12 consecutive school days in December. The exercises are all Christmas themed and last no longer than 10 minutes each. 


The coronavirus pandemic is the biggest challenge the BHF has faced in its 60-year history. All 750 BHF shops were forced to close and dozens of fundraising events remain cancelled. The BHF has been losing over £10 million a month and devastatingly, they may need to cut their research budget in half this year. Heart and circulatory diseases remain the world’s biggest killers affecting millions of people worldwide. They don’t disappear because of a global pandemic. They continue to cause heartbreak on a devastating scale and that is why TSA are very proud to be supporting the BHF this Christmas by taking part in their Elf Kick Challenge.

pageSummary: I am raising money by going sober in December because of the increase in Heart Attacks since Covid-19
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising money by going sober in December
pageSummaryWhy: of the increase in Heart Attacks since Covid-19
story:
You heard it right; No alcohol in December what so ever! That means a completely sober Christmas and New Year! Why are you torturing yourself like this Chelsie you may ask!! To begin, thank you for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. There have been almost 800 excess deaths in those dying below the age of 65 from heart and circulatory diseases since the Covid-19 pandemic began, new analysis has revealed. Excess deaths from heart diseases in under 65s remained disturbingly high even after the first peak - with rates almost 13% higher than usual between May and July.

The pandemic has also had a devastating effect on the  income of the BHF,  which will drastically impact future research. The expected investment drop in new research is at £50 million due to the pandemic, so people like me and you should do our bit in raising money for the cause!  

Two huge motivators behind this fundraiser are Stephen Oliver, and John Atkinson, both massive characters who touched many hearts in their lives. Raising money for the BHF during these unprecedented times would mean a lot to me, so their amazing work can continue.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
Our Dad Dennis Mitchell passed away peacefully on 4th November 2020, five days before his 93rd birthday. He had a stroke on 15th September, then after a short spell in hospital spent his last few weeks in The Springs Care Home, Malvern, where he received excellent care. 

After graduating from the Royal School of Mines, Imperial College London, Dad emigrated to Canada where he worked as a lecturer and mining engineer. Having married his childhood sweetheart Vera, he returned to the UK in 1955, when he started a career in the steel industry which culminated in his appointment as Managing Director at Round Oak Steel Works. Having retired earlier than planned when Round Oak was forced to close in late 1982, he was then instrumental in setting up a training company in the West Midlands, MOST (Midlands Oak Skills and Technology), and later was awarded MBE for services to training in the West Midlands.

During the last few years of his working life, Dad suffered from palpitations – he was in his late 60’s when he had his first heart attack. This was followed by cardiac surgery - a quadruple by-pass at the age of 69 – and then a pacemaker. The treatment he received from the health service, both here and in Madeira where he and our Mum spent their holidays, enabled him to have a long, happy and active retirement. He loved sailing, particularly in Pembrokeshire where he and our Mum lived for 25 years, and was a member of Pembroke Haven Yacht Club, including a term as Commodore; he was also an active member of Tenby Golf Club, taking on the role of Club Captain for a while; and he and our Mum would walk for miles along the levadas when on their holidays in Madeira.

When Mum and Dad moved to Herefordshire in later years, both became enthusiastic regulars at the local BHF cardiac rehabilitation keep fit classes, and Dad carried on playing at Dymock Golf Club up until about 3 years ago, not long before his 90th birthday!

We hope that your donation to the British Heart Foundation will enable others to live their lives to the full after cardiac surgery in the way that our Dad did. To live well for 24 years after a quadruple by-pass – not bad!

Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

Dennis Mitchell's children, Deborah, Philippa and Keith

pageSummary: I am raising money because It was my father's favourite charity.
pageSummaryWhy: It was my father's favourite charity.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.  

My father passed away this week, and in the current situation it will be at least 3 weeks before we can even start making arrangements.  When we do, the funeral will be covid compliant, and we wanted to give the people that knew him an opportunity to express themselves in the meantime, and he thought 'flowers were a bloody waste of time!' 

So we would love instead if those that knew him could instead make a donation, either here or directly to, the British Heart Foundation, without whose research he wouldn't have lived to a stubborn 81 years old.  Their work made his survival of 4 major heart attacks, 11 stents, and AF possible. He also said that daughters caused the heart attacks in the first place 😉.  

We will miss his gentle presence,  his wisdom and his humour, and would like done good to come of his passing. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. pageSummaryWhat: I am running (and occasionally walking) 874 miles
pageSummaryWhy: it’ll help fund more life saving research
story:
A lot of people already know why British Heart Foundation is my charity of choice - as someone living with Heart Disease for over 20 years, the research carried out by BHF and the work of NHS cardio specialists are the reason I’m still here to take on these challenges!

The latest mission...

Run 874 miles from Lands End to John O’Groats as part of the #lejog8 virtual race held by EndtoEnd.run.

I’ll be chipping away at the distance over the next few months, whilst building up to completing a marathon to finish the event. Anyone that knows me (and my aversion to running) will know how much of a physical and psychological challenge this is going to be.

I know times are tough for everyone, but please give whatever you can and  show your support to a great charity.

story:
Previous years have seen the OCD Pencoed PENTEN and OITC teams raising significant amount of monies for numerous charities and good causes.

The Coronavirus Pandemic this year has significantly impacted the monies being donated to these worthwhile charities - money that is desperately needed to continue research and support functions of those charities.

Therefore the PENTEN and OITC teams have proposed a "Virtual" event where people may take part on the same day but in their own time whilst maintaining social distancing rules, OCD shift workers may also choose a different day to take part. Therefore for 2020 we will be raising money for the British Heart Foundation.

I will be doing the 20 Miles Bike Ride Challenge. I'm aiming to do my challenge either on the 1st or the 4th of December due to working shifts. Thank you for the support.
