story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. 

I have the honour and privilege of being 2021 Club Captain for Burnham on Crouch Golf Club and have chosen BHF as one of the charities I will be raising funds for.

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. Unfortunately this includes members of my own family and members of our golfing family who have left us far too early.

It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. Thanks!

pageSummary: Performing tunes in memory of Tonya Kaye because we lost her far too soon in December 2019
pageSummaryWhat: Performing tunes in memory of Tonya Kaye
pageSummaryWhy: we lost her far too soon in December 2019
story:
December 2020 marks a year since Tonya left us suddenly. She leaves a gaping void which can never be filled, but we’re going to fill some of it with songs.

She loved music and we loved singing with her. Please join us in dedicating a ‘Tune for Tonya’. The rules:

1. Donate - whatever you can spare to this page
2. Share a song - upload a video of you singing or lipsyncing to a song to the Facebook group or any social media using #tunefortonya
3. Nominate at least one person to do the same.

Let’s remember Tonya the best way we know how and make some noise. Starts December 1st.

We’re raising money for the British Heart Foundation since Tonya tragically died of a heart attack. 

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help us hit our target. Thanks!

story:
I've decided to do a virtual walk covering the entire length of the UK from Lands End To John O Groats, which is 874 Miles over a 12 month period.

For those friends and family that know me, this is not the usual thing this couch potato would do.

I have decided to try and lose the lockdown weight caused by an over indulgence of chocolate hob-nobs and get fit by challenging myself with this virtual walk and raise money along the way.

Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. £24 could pay for two hours of research by an early career scientist, but every pound helps so please give what you can to help me hit my target. charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. Vascular dementia. Diabetes. They're all connected, and they're all under our microscope. Together we can beat heartbreak forever.
charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
There are around 340,000 people living with heart and circulatory diseases in Wales and it causes more than 1 in 4 of all deaths in Wales, or around 9,600 deaths each year - that's an average of 26 people each day.  

The coronavirus pandemic is the biggest challenge the BHF has faced in their 60-year history.

While the world has been on lockdown, heart and circulatory diseases havent. Theyve still been tearing families apart, ending lives too soon and snatching away peoples quality of life. They are still the worlds biggest killers and no matter what else is happening, Research has helped the BHF gain so much ground over the last few decades, and its the only way they are going to get to the finish line. 

We want to raise funds to support research at Welsh universities, so no one has to go through the heartbreak of losing someone to this awful disease.

Please support us this Christmas so we can help BHF Cymru beat heartbreak forever.

eventName: In memory of Dr. Asim Kumar Sen
pageSummary: Running 5km in memory of my father Dr A.K. Sen because it is the 15th anniversary of his passing.
pageSummaryWhat: Running 5km in memory of my father Dr A.K. Sen
pageSummaryWhy: it is the 15th anniversary of his passing.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am training to run 5km (without stopping!) on 17.1.21 which will mark 15 years since my father suddenly passed away. His death left seismic waves not only in our family's lives but in every life he touched. He was truly 'one of a kind' and I am not shy to say, the best doctor I have ever had the privilege to meet - he was my inspiration.

My Dad had significant struggles with his own personal health having had a quadruple bypass at Bart's in 1987, I was 5 years old, my sister 10. I remember those long drives to London from Southend with my mum and sister, visiting Dad while he was recovering, which in itself was turbulent to say the least.

You wouldn't have known this about my Dad as he was not one to let difficulties stop him or get the better of him. Instead, challenges were his driving force and he continued to be a successful single-handed award winning GP.

For as long as I can remember, my Dad woke up at 5.30am everyday and ran 5 miles, which was followed by weight training. He did this every day, before taking me to school and then doing a full surgery of 35 patients, his day would also include home visits and at least one care home or nursing home visits too. He somehow managed to fit in picking me up from school in his 'lunch hour' before heading back to work - I have no idea how he managed this... but he did this so well and always with a smile on his face and a joke or two to tell!

My Dad and Mum mum raised money annually for local hospital charities where my Dad had the opportunity to partake in his favourite hobby.... singing. He was a wonderful and dedicated singer, again diligently practising this art daily. He made life look 'easy', because I think he had this mindset and perspective. Those who knew him never knew what he endured because he saw the the bright side of life and saw struggles as the making of us. This is a teaching I hold on to, especially in these very difficult times we are living in.

Unfortunately, my Dad was unable to tolerate 'innovative' procedures in 2005 which ultimately led to his untimely departure in January 2006, just 5 months later.

So, why am I running 5km?

5km for some is 'easy-peasy' and if my younger self could speak to me now, I'm sure I would be having some stern words about the deconditioned state I am in!

Having had several physical health set backs, I have been unable to keep on 'tip-top' form, but now, my pledge to my father, as it is coming up to the 15th anniversary of his passing, is to look after myself, just as he looked after himself so diligently. His physical activity is what kept him alive for 18 years following his bypass. If he had no excuse, then I certainly don't.

Along with my sister, we've decided to do the the couch to 5km over the next 9 weeks to align with my dad's anniversary on 17.1.21. So, on 17.1.21 we will be able to do the a full 5km without stopping. Now, this is not the 5miles he did, but that will be our next target!

If you are in a position to donate, please do, but please do not feel obliged. If you are not in a position to donate, thank you for reading this and learning about my Dad's journey. He was a true gentleman and a great GP.

Keep well and keep safe.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Thank you for visiting this page.  2020 has been quite a year!  It has been difficult for many and charities are struggling too, so I thought that in lieu of a Christmas gift I would see if I could raise funds for a good cause instead.

As most of you know, my Dad had heart difficulties a while ago and again recently which resulted in him receiving an amazing little gadget which keeps his heart at a regular rhythm - the Rolls Royce of heart devices.  It has made such a significant difference to him.  These devices are only available due to the dedication and hard work of clever people working for organisations such as the British Heart Foundation; so I have chosen them as the charity for my Christmas Gifts.

The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people lose their lives. story: Our BT & EE Sales, Corporate, Future Services and SME teams are fundraising for the British Heart Foundation by taking on the Everest Sherpa Challenge between 9th November to 6th December 2020. During these difficult COVID times, it's so important to us to be giving something back to our wider community and society in general, and as such our employees have committed to this challenge with great determination in the hope that we can really make a difference. Unfortunately, there are very few of us who have not been touched by heart or circulatory disease, stroke, dementia, diabetes within our own families/friend's circle. We hope you will be able to support us to raise some much needed funds for the BHF - this would mean so much to all of us. Every little counts and we greatly appreciate it! Our teams comprise 5 climbers per team, and every team has committed to achieve the Everest virtual climb within a 4 week period. Thank You!

pageSummary: London Landmarks Half Marathon 2021 because I am finally ready to be brave and run a half!
pageSummaryWhy: I am finally ready to be brave and run a half!
story:
Thank you  for visiting my page. I am raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support.

 The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease (including stroke, vascular dementia and even diabetes) in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people still lose their lives. My dad and his brothers have all been diagnosed with heart conditions recently. We lost my Grandad to the cruel grasps of Dementia in 2012 as well as the many strokes he had already suffered and my Gran from the effects of Diabetes in 2019.

They would have thought my running crazy, but I want to push myself and make them, my family and myself proud and do this in their memory. 💪🏻

Please donate and sponsor me anything you can to help me hit my target and keep me going on the 23rd May. (Covid depending!) 

13miles/21km here I come!

Thank you :-)

Els x

charity.description: With your support, we aim to fund over £100 million of research each year into all heart and circulatory diseases and the things that cause them. Heart diseases. Stroke. charity.name: British Heart Foundation
story:
The pandemic is the biggest challenge weve faced in our 60 year history. And its led to us being forced to make the devastating decision to cut our 2020 research budget in half. So the truth is, weve never needed people like you more. 

Virtual fundraising challenges like Dechox are a way to help us keep up the pace of progress. Your willpower will be funnelled into groundbreaking science and support for the people who need us most. Because despite everything else happening at the moment, heart and circulatory diseases are still the worlds biggest killers. For the sake of our mums and dads, brothers and sisters, grandparents and friends - we cant drop the ball now.

story:
Thanks for visiting my page. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation by running the London Landmarks Half Marathon, and I'd be so grateful for your support. 

In memory of Alain Sutton 28/5/1954-6/11/2020

There was no warning. On the 6th November 2020, my dad suddenly passed away from heart disease. Dad had been keeping himself safe inside since his retirement due to Covid-19. He had so many holidays and experiences planned. I am keen to support the BHF to help raise money for research into treatments to prevent others losing their lives too early.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: I am running for because it has the potential to save many lives.
pageSummaryWhy: it has the potential to save many lives.
story:
Thanks for visiting my page.

On May the 23rd, I will be running the London Landmarks.

In March 2018, my brother who was 26 at the time suffered from a heart attack but luckily bounced back is now living his life to the full. Unfortunately, there is a history of heart disease in my family and I sadly lost my Granddad to a heart condition. I would like make my loved ones who are no longer here proud of me.  

In the UK, heart and circulatory diseases kill 1 in 4 people, which devastates many families every year. I'm raising money for the British Heart Foundation and I'd be so grateful for your support. The BHF has helped halve the number of people dying from heart and circulatory disease in the UK but sadly every day hundreds of people continue to lose their lives. It's only thanks to support from people like us that the BHF can create new treatments and discover new cures. This is a great cause that I would love to raise money for, every pound helps so I would be forever grateful if you could support towards this amazing charity and join me on this journey!

Thank you, 

Zoe.

charity.name: British Heart Foundation
pageSummary: Running further than ever in memory of my Dad
pageSummaryWhat: Running further than ever in memory of my Dad
story:
I may be mad but I have signed up to run a half marathon in May 21. I have never run a half or come anywhere near it. This is something I want to do for me and this is something I want to do for my Dad but I need your help with sponsorship please.

It is 25 years since my Dad died from a heart attack. He was 53. We never saw it coming. I was 21 and my brothers were 18, 15 and 11. My mum was left to bring us up and run a business full-time. I think it is fair to say it was never the same, we never got the chance to build adult relationships with him. He never saw us settle down or get to meet his grandchildren. As sad as that is it isn’t unusual as 1 in 4 people still die from heart and circulatory diseases now.

British Heart Foundation research has provided us with machines that can restart hearts, fix arteries not just in adults but in tiny babies and even give someone a heart they weren’t born with. Who knows what is still to be found. Covid 19 has cut the ability to fund new research in half so funding is needed more than ever at the moment so this seemed like the year to do something.P

Please help me raise funds for this charity, it would mean a lot to me. It goes without saying every penny counts so if you can help me I would be so grateful. 

I do know that if my Dad is looking down he is likely to be in shock that I am planning to run full stop never mind a half marathon!

charity.description: The ability to get around is vital in order to live a full life yet thousands of people with sight loss never leave home alone. We empower visually impaired people to do that and rely on the support of the public to fund the guide dog service.
charity.name: Guide Dogs
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
story:
The 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas Collection

Help us as we aim to raise enough to support 12 brand new guide dogs this Christmas!

During December the four-legged volunteers of the Southampton Fundraising Group would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at collections and events in your community.

Due to the current situation, we’re not able to be out as much this festive season, and we know you will miss seeing our life-changing doggy volunteers! We’re hoping you will help us and donate to our ‘12 Guide Dogs of Christmas’ Collection as we aim to raise enough for 12 new guide dog partnerships! 

It costs over £56,000 to fund the lifetime cost of a guide dog. Please consider donating £12 during our 12-day collection so we can fund 12 new life-changers this Christmas.

We appreciate that times are difficult, but for people with sight loss, social isolation can be their everyday. You can help them feel less alone, now and in the future.

Don’t forget to send it on through Facebook, WhatsApp, email or text and get your friends and family involved too.

Thank you and Merry Christmas!

story:
100 for Guide Dogs is your challenge, your way. You can choose to Run100, Cycle100 or Swim100 between 1 July and 31 November. However you take on your 100, get sponsored to do it and help us supporting people living with sight loss. 

You could complete 100 metres, 100 minutes, 100 days  be creative!

The sponsorship money you raise will make a difference. £100 could pay for five hours' training at a Guide Dogs training school.

It's thanks to people like you that we can continue to provide life-changing services, like our guide dogs, to people with sight loss. So, a huge thank you and lots of luck for your challenge!

#TeamGuideDogs

pageSummary: Cycling 1,420kms in 20 days because they get people out of potential lifelong lockdown
pageSummaryWhy: they get people out of potential lifelong lockdown
story:
5 years ago a 12 y.o. Laurence rode John O'Grouts to Landsend solo. It took him 20 days to ride the 1,420 kms. Laurence journey is here: https://laurencejogle.wordpress.com/

In honour of his achievement I would like to make use of this second lockdown to raise money for Guide Dogs. They run many programmes to help visually impaired out of potential lifelong lockdown.

As well as the guide dog programme, they run many programmes for children and adults to help build the confidence to lead an active life. Full details here: https://www.guidedogs.org.uk/getting-support.

Let's come together in our short-term lockdown, to helps others out of their more permanent one.

story:
Almost two million people in the UK are living with sight loss that has a significant impact on their daily lives. Of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone and lead lonely, isolated lives. 

Guide Dogs works for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life, for a world where being blind or partially sighted is not what defines you. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling hopes and dreams.

charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
eventName: Guide Dog Name a Pup Number 10
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

The Berkshire Puppy Walkers are at it again.  Having raised enough money to name 9 Guide Dog puppies (£2500 each time) we have decided to keep going to name another amazing life changing dog to assist a blind or visually impaired person.  This has been done by selling unwanted items and holding events such as silent auctions, open gardens, afternoon teas, craft stalls, car boot sales, a murder mystery evening, raffles, name a teddy stalls, teddy tombolas etc. We have to date named Beegee, Annie, Jenny, Nicky, Teddy, Yvie, Pringle, Sandi and during the craziness of 2020, Zoom!

It costs Guide Dogs £56,800 to support a guide dog from birth to retirement.  Please help us in funding one of these wonderful dogs to give back independence to someone.

Almost two million people in the UK are living with sight loss that has a significant impact on their daily lives. Of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone and lead lonely, isolated lives. Guide Dogs works for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life, for a world where being blind or partially sighted is not what defines you. A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling hopes and dreams.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummary: Naming a Guide Dog pup in memory of GD Clover
pageSummaryWhat: Naming a Guide Dog pup in memory of GD Clover
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page

Clover held the special honour of being ‘a life changer’ in carrying out the role of Guide Dog until she sadly passed away the day before her 12th Birthday in 2019. She carried out her role as a Guide Dog so diligently and continued in her retirement to be a very valuable member of our fundraising group. Clover was an amazing ambassador for Guide Dogs, she had a loving & friendly nature you couldn’t help but smile when you met her.

The loss of Clover is deeply felt by all who came into contact with her and therefore it was decided that we would like to honour this 'life changer' by raising enough funds to name a puppy in her memory.

charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 209617 and Scotland SC038979
eventName: 4 years of mobility & independence with my guide dog Hannah
pageSummary: 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas virtual fundraiser because of my wonderful guide dog Hannah
pageSummaryWhat: 12 Guide Dogs of Christmas virtual fundraiser
pageSummaryWhy: of my wonderful guide dog Hannah
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. I'm raising money for Guide Dogs this Christmas by holding my own virtual collection. Christmas marks a very special time for me as I qualified with my guide dog Hannah in the run up to Christmas in 2016. This December I'm celebrating 4 fantastic years of mobility and independence with Hannah by my side.

Typically in December hundreds of our guide dogs across the UK would usually be out and about wagging their tails and meeting you at supermarket and street collections, Christmas fairs and festive coffee mornings. Our four-legged fundraisers support the 400+ fundraising groups across the UK but unfortunately due to the current situation, most of our fundraising groups will not be out collecting this festive season, and our four-legged fundraisers will be very much missed! I hope you will get involved and support Guide Dog's Christmas campaign, which aims to raise enough to fund 12 new guide dog partnerships for people like me who have been affected by sight loss.

My Story:

I have the eye condition, Glaucoma, which was first diagnosed 20 years ago. At first my eye condition did not cause me many problems and I was able to continue my job as a Physical Education teacher in West Sussex but my life changed in 2008 when I was registered blind/partially sighted. Not being able to drive meant my job was untenable as I couldn't take the school teams to and from matches in the minibus. 

Before teaching I was a professional football player and had a good football career representing my country at every level; schoolboy, youth, intermediate (under 23) and finally achieving full England Honours. I played for many top teams, including Burnley, Everton, Middlesbrough,Portsmouth, QPR and Wolverhampton, as well as playing in the North American soccer league for Vancouver Whitecaps.

After losing my sight I had three operations but unfortunately there they made no improvement to my vision.  Although I still enjoyed golf, fly fishing, carriage driving and gardening, I had to rely on family and friends to take me out. At first I didn't think I needed a guide dog, I guess I was in denial about how much my sight had deteriorated. However a bad experience at Epsom races changed my attitude. It was supposed to be a fun day out with the family but the huge crowds made me really anxious. We ended up leaving early becuase I couldn't cope and thought I was going to walk into everyone. For weeks afterwards I felt low and socially I didn't feel comfortable.

I admitted to myself that I needed some help, and after a chat with Brenda we decided to contact Guide Dogs. The support I recieved during the application process alone made a huge difference. While waiting on a guide dog I recieved long cane training which helped me recover my independence and taught me numerous skills to enable me to get out and about safely despite my loss of vision.  I am hugely grateful to the Newcastle Guide Dogs team who helped me to accept my sight loss and who gave me the skills and confidence to get out and about again and live life without limits.

In 2017 I was matched to my guide dog Hannah, a yellow Labrador, and we bonded immediately! Hannah has made an incredible difference to my life. Since qualifying she has enabled me to travel across the country to visit friends and family, and to various fundraising events for Guide Dogs. She has even helped me navigate the busy streets of London, which was unimaginable before. I've written a book about my life and experience of sight loss, and became a fundraising volunteer and speaker for Guide Dogs to raise awareness of their work and to help other people who have lost their sight. Sight loss has been life changing, but so is Hannah!

Help Guide Dogs raise enough funds this Christmas to fund 12 new guide dog partnerships. You can get involved by donating to my page, by sharing across social media and by nominating a friend, family member or colleague to get involved.

A huge thank you for all your kind support. I've been completely overwhelmed by the response to my fundraising, from friends, family, past pupils and football fans, since I started fundraising for Guide Dogs. 

Thank you so much and please do continue the phenomenal support for such a well-deserved charity.

Many thanks.

David Thomas

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

As you will be aware, Cathie recently passed away and her wish was that instead of flowers we would have donations to the guide dogs. Mum was supported hugely by guide dogs when her sight started to deteriorate. And this resulted in Ruby becoming part of our family. Mum was always trying to fund raise for them to repay the debt and so this is a fitting memory.

story:
In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.

Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.

We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.

A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:
A few years ago, my dad was diagnosed with dry macular degeneration. This is a rare condition which slowly affects your vision and can leave you partially sighted or blind. Therefore, one day, my dad may require the assistance of a guide dog. Hopefully, his vision will not deteriorate to the state where he requires a guide dog and it won’t come to this. However, if it does I would like to give as much back as possible to this fantastic charity. After all, dogs are absolute life savers and in this instance of being a guide dog they are amazing. Dogs truly are a mans best friend.

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation. Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

story:
If you know Niamh, you know she ran her first half marathon in February 2020, and couldn't walk properly for about 2 months after. So why run again you might ask? Dogs! 

In the UK today, almost two million people are living with sight loss and of those, around 180,000 rarely leave their homes alone. Many suffer from depression and struggle with feelings of isolation.Guide Dogs is here to help solve this problem. We provide individual support that overcomes the emotional and physical challenges faced by people living with sight loss.We work for a world where people with sight loss are never left out of life. We work for a world where blind people no longer feel invisible, where the quality of their eye sight is genuinely the only difference between them and the rest of society.A world with enough support to make the challenges of sight loss no barrier to fulfilling your needs and dreams. A world where being blind or partially sighted isn't what defines you.

Normally when Niamh and Jack get together, their time includes lots of alcohol, probably shouting at Don Broco or Jonas Brothers, and generally being a bit of a mess. Running together will be a real challenge for them, and hopefully just as fun too! If you can't donate, please feel free to meet us at the end with a mix of vegan & non vegan snacks, fizzy vimto, or a bottle of prosecco.

story:
Every December  The Stage Pub  Nottingham  collects money to help poorly children  that are less fortunate then us.

Last year we raised a fair sum of money, with the help of The ex Players workers, which went to wish upon a star charity.

This year is proven a bit difficult due to covid lockdowns so we have decided to set up a just giving page.

We have chosen Great Ormond Street children's hospital this year as our charity.

All I can ask is please take the time to think about this charity and kindly donate.

No matter how little or much you donate, it is a very worthy cause.

Thanks Richard

eventName: In memory of This page is found in memory of Arthur  Manson
pageSummary: We are collecting donations because its dedicated to children's healthcare worldwide
pageSummaryWhy: its dedicated to children's healthcare worldwide
story:
Arthur Manson was born on the 10th of November 2020 with a rare condition known as a Diaphragmatic Hernia, which tragically led to his early passing. During his life, he was loved by his mother Charlotte, his father Mathieu and his big brother Victor. 


As close friends of the family, we wanted to honour his memory by offering people a way to support a worthy cause. We have set up this page to collect donations for Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity; GOSH is dedicated to children’s healthcare and to finding new and better ways to treat childhood illnesses. 

In loving memory of  Arthur Manson, 
10 November 2020 - 16 November 2020

pageSummary: I am running 1.5miles a day until Christmas Eve because I want to help children less fortunate than me.
pageSummaryWhat: I am running 1.5miles a day until Christmas Eve
pageSummaryWhy: I want to help children less fortunate than me.
story:
After watching Children In Need,  Freddie decided he wanted to do something to help those children less fortunate than himself.

Freddie is a fit, healthy, energetic 9 year old from Lincoln. With a love for all sports he has set himself the challenge of running 1.5 miles a day from now until Christmas Eve! 🎅🏼 

Running outdoors in all weathers or on the treadmill in the garage, he is determined to push himself to complete this daily challenge.  

The running commenced on Saturday 14th November 2020. That’s a total of 40 days, covering a whopping 60 miles, the distance of over 2 marathons!!!

Please show your support by donating whatever you can. No matter how big or small, every penny will be greatly appreciated & go towards reaching his £150 target for his chosen Children’s Charity.

Many thanks for your support 🏃‍♂️💪 🎄 

Day 1 - target already increased due to your amazing generosity & support 👏

pageSummary: Teaching important skills in prevention & response because raising awareness could potentially save a life.
pageSummaryWhat: Teaching important skills in prevention & response
pageSummaryWhy: raising awareness could potentially save a life.
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our page.

2020 has been an unprecedented year with so many families locked down at home without any knowledge of what to do in case of an emergency with their babies and infants.

By offering this awareness course, 5779 hope to provide key skills in CPR, Choking, Recovery, Anaphylaxis and Shock for babies and infants and we would like to appeal to the community to support the incredible work carried out daily by the amazing staff at Great Ormond Street Hospital, we are forever grateful to them.

From all of us at 5779, we thank you for your donation and support.

eventName: Clayton City of London to The North Pole
pageSummary: Cycling 3851km to The North Pole before Xmas Eve because we want to help as much as we can for Christmas
pageSummaryWhat: Cycling 3851km to The North Pole before Xmas Eve
pageSummaryWhy: we want to help as much as we can for Christmas
story:
Hi Everyone,

This is the Clayton Hotel City of London and we are raising money for Christmas for our nominated charity Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity. This charity is close to all our hearts accross Clayton hotels and we want to raise some money to help in time for Christmas!

This is the story of our fundraiser...............

Santa Clause & Mrs Clause have been on a weekend break and have got stuck in the lockdown 2.0 at the Clayton City of London, it's our mission to get them back! We are cycling the distance 3851km from the UK to the North Pole to get him back in time for Christmas Eve, when he will be delivering all the gifts. We know this is going to take a lot of hard work but we believe we can get them back just in time. You can track our progress on our social account, Strava & through the hotel. 

Thank you so much for reading & any donations are appreciated from all of us here at the Clayton Hotel City of London.

pageSummary: We are trying to help seriously ill children because families should be together at Christmas
pageSummaryWhat: We are trying to help seriously ill children
pageSummaryWhy: families should be together at Christmas
story:
Please join me and the team/ children from Maggie & Rose Nurseries and Family Members’ Club for a fun day with Christmas songs, dancing and a Toddler Walkathon trying to raise money for the families with ill childre at GOSH, so they can be together for Christmas

The event takes place: 

10/12  02.00pm

Turnham Green Park near the Church

There will be singing, dancing, cheering for the toddlers, a santa, a few live princesses, cake and much more (and the mayor of Hounslow might drop by too) 

We will have donation buckets in case you wish to donate to this very important cause :-)

FACT: Every day brings new challenges at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH). Every day, over 600 children and young people from across the UK arrive for life-changing treatments. 

Every day, the brightest minds come together to achieve pioneering medical breakthroughs that change the lives of thousands of children – and change the world.

This extraordinary hospital has always depended on charitable support, and every day is a chance for you to make a difference.

At Christmas, time spent with the people you love is precious. Although GOSH Charity try to ensure that as many children as possible can be home for Christmas, some will need to stay at the hospital.  Your amazing support this year will help to keep children and their families together during this special time by helping to fund the family accommodation. 

With travelling to and from the hospital being much more challenging than before and with many hotels no longer being an option to stay at, our family accommodation is a lifeline for families at what can be a stressful and upsetting time. Seriously ill children receiving life changing treatment want to be metres from their families, not miles. 

Just £35 covers the cost for one family to stay for one night and every year over 2,000 patients and families will stay in the charity-funded accommodation.  One of the greatest comforts you can give a child in hospital this Christmas is making sure their loved ones are never far away.  

Thank you so much for helping to keep families together over this special time.

pageSummary: I am Tania I'm raising money for Christmas because I cannot express my gratitude to the staff.
pageSummaryWhat: I am Tania I'm raising money for Christmas
pageSummaryWhy: I cannot express my gratitude to the staff.
story:
Hi I'm Tania 

Most of our family and friends will already know but our eldest daughter Emma has suffered with rare episodes of fevers on a regular basis since she turned 6 months old. It was heart breaking for us as her parents watching her in hospital beds every month burning up at fevers of 42°. 

 It wasn't till 2018 when we finally got referred to GOSH that we started to get an understanding of her condition. I cannot fault the staff for the support and care. Not just with Emma but always following up on my mental health too. 

We are so fortunate that Emma gets to spend Christmas at home with us. But the reality is some children don't. I have this fundraiser in hope that it gives the hospital funds to make Christmas a little bit more especial for children.

We normally buy toys to donate but with the current pandemic I thought this would be better. I would like to thank anyone who shows your support.
title: Tania's Great Ormond Street Christmas

charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story:
On Friday 11th December, we are hosting “The Qx Factor” the first global talent competition within the insurance, pensions and investments community.

The event is in aid of Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity, so please do get behind this great cause this Christmas.

Every child should have the chance to be at home with their families for Christmas Day. Dedicated teams at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) work around the clock to find cures and treatments to ensure seriously ill children have the best chance of getting home to their families. And, for those children whose treatment needs to continue over the festive season, they try to make the hospital feel like a home from home.

Your support can help bring Christmas to the hospital, making it feel like a home from home for those children and their families. And your donations also mean you’re helping to fund important services for GOSH staff working to care for the children over Christmas.

Together we can help GOSH get more seriously ill children home to their families.

story:

pageSummaryWhat: We are hosting a fun, charity Christmas quiz night
pageSummaryWhy: we want to help children in need this Christmas.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

Dylan and Hayden are hosting a fun-filled, online quiz to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital this Christmas. As teachers, we see first-hand the health issues that a number of children face and we massively appreciate the hard work that various organisations and health care professionals put in to treating and protecting our most vulnerable children. Whether physical or mental, the wellbeing of our children is something we value extremely highly and is why we have chosen this charity for our fundraiser.

We will match any amount of money we raise on this page up to our target of £500. That means if you donate £10, we will donate £10. Together, we could raise £1000 to help children who need it the most!

The quiz will take place on Saturday 19th December at 7pm via Zoom. Once signed up (see below), you will be sent all the details you need to access the event. The content will be appropriate for all ages and should serve as a lovely way for the community to come together, have a good time and raise money for a worthy cause.

To take part in the quiz, all we ask is that a donation be made to this page and for you to sign up via the form below. You can find the link to the google form below. 

Recommended donation: £10 per team (or as much as you can spare!)

https://forms.gle/WchxUvR7eB6McDZz7

The more people who sign up, the more money we raise for charity!

eventName: The Grape Gals : A Holiday Wine Tasting
story:
The Grape Gals 
We all know this Christmas is shaping up to be a little different. Instead of the usual holiday parties, take the start of Christmas week virtual this year and join the Grape Gals for our first festive tasting. We’re so excited to spend the evening taking you through four delicious bottles hand selected by Ida and the usual questions and quizzes from Paige. 

The Wine
From Sparkling to Sweet, get in the festive spirit with four delicious wines from across the world.
- Breaky Bottom Cuvée Gerard Hoffnung Brut Traditional Method 2009, England (£34.95)
- Egy Kis Dry Furmint Barta 2019, Hungary, (£14.95)
- Chateau Barrail du Blanc Grand Cru St-Emilion 2016, France (£23.95) 
- Sticky Mickey Late Harvest Sauvignon Blanc Eradus 2017 Halves, New Zealand (£12.95)    

Either include the four tasting wines with your Christmas order (£85.00) or add two bottles of C&B’s delicious Sparkling Blanc de Blancs to make up an ideal holiday case (£110.00).

The Logistics 
Join us on Zoom for an hour while we take you through each of the four bottles. Ida takes an analytical and comparative approach to each wine.
If you would like to join please email ida.weatherall@corneyandbarrow.com with the following details as soon as possible, and latest by Monday 14th December.

Name
Billing address
Delivery address
Email address
Contact number
Order option (If adding to an order we are happy to provide suggestions for suitable festive drinking!)

This will also make a wonderful Christmas gift so think of loved ones far away.

Great Ormond Street Hospital, Infant Leukaemia Research
We are raising money for Infant Leukaemia research at GOSH, in memory of dear friend of the Grape Gals, Alice’s nephew Enzo.

Enzo was diagnosed with Infant Leukaemia as a baby, and tragically passed away- aged two and a half earlier this year. Infant leukaemia (affecting babies diagnosed before the age of one), has been described as ‘A thorn in the side of a remarkable success story’. Although there have been incredible improvements for childhood leukaemia over the past twenty years - where survival rates are as high as 90%, the main type of leukaemia affecting babies, is still not well understood and remains hard to treat.

GOSH are looking to find a cure for this aggressive disease and find alternative treatments to the particularly high-dose chemotherapy used in its standard treatment, and also bone marrow transplants, which in themselves carry a 10-20% fatality rate for these patients.

As always if you are not able to donate, please consider signing up as a blood donor! #Blood4Enzo

pageSummary: Christmas Baby Dress Up because families deserve to be close to their children
pageSummaryWhy: families deserve to be close to their children
story:
Keeping families together during difficult times is vital. £35 could pay for a one night stay in our patient and family accommodation close to Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH), so parents from Essex and across the UK can stay close by while their child is in hospital. Our new Never Far Away: Essex Appeal aims to raise vital funds to support parent and family accommodation at GOSH. £300,000 will give families precious nights close to their children whilst they receive treatment at GOSH. We are asking the people of Essex to get behind this appeal, together we can make a massive difference to the families who are going through a very stressful time, if we can ease one worry then it is worth it. Whether you can raise £1 or £100; it will make an impact to so many families. A 7-night stay for 2 adults in a budget hotel 15 minutes from the hospital would cost a staggering £815. This is simply not affordable for most families.Find out more at www.gosh.org/NeverFarAway

At Basking Babies we’ve been running events to raise money for this vital appeal for the past couple of years and did not want multiple lockdowns during 2020 to stop us! 

During the month of December we’ll be asking mums to dress up their babies in something Christmassy across all our Baby Massage and Baby Yoga classes in Essex. We can’t wait to see those babies dressed up so sweetly and to raise some vital funds for families who need to stay close to their loved ones in the process 💜

pageSummary: 31 because they have looked after my son since birth
pageSummaryWhy: they have looked after my son since birth
story:
This January, I'm kickstarting 2021 by taking part in Running off Christmas. I'll be running 31 miles throughout the month to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity (GOSH Charity).

Those who know me, know I dislike running (exercise in general!)! Those who also know me, know that almost 4 years ago our beautiful boisterous baby boy was born with his bladder on the outside of his body. For 4 years I’ve said to myself I would like to give back to the utterly incredible Great Ormond Street Hospital and the care we have and continue to receive for Henry. Henry’s undergone 2 surgeries at GOSH, one when he was only 48hrs old, the other when he was 18 months. I can not thank the hospital enough and to put myself out of my comfort zone for 31 miles over the course of a month doesn’t even seem enough...I’m sure I’ll regret that statement come January 1st!!! 

I’m fully aware this year has thrown a curve ball to us all, but if you could donate anything to support GOSH I’d be more grateful than you realise!! Plus it would mean I would have to pull on the big girl pants and actually run!!! 😱😱

pageSummary: Scrapping dry January to run a soggy 31 miles because it's the most brilliant hospital!
pageSummaryWhat: Scrapping dry January to run a soggy 31 miles
story:
This January, I'm kickstarting 2021 by taking part in Running off Christmas. I'll be running 31 miles throughout the month to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity (GOSH Charity). 

On 13 June 2015 my amazing brother Jasper was born. Within hours of his arrival he suffered a collapse and we were told he had suffered a massive intraventricular bleed in his brain and that he was fighting for his life. In the early hours Jasper was taken by CATS transfer team to Great Ormond Street Hospital for emergency surgery. 

He spent the first 3 and a half months of his life in Great Ormond Street and underwent ten surgeries in his first 6 months under the incredible care of NICU & the Neurosurgery team on Koala Ward, his first being on the day after his birth.  We are utterly indebted to the skill, care and compassion of all at Great Ormond Street Hospital. So here's my way of giving back and raising money for this fabulous hospital that saved Jasper's life.

It's quick, easy and secure to donate, just press the Give Now button! GOSH's patients, families and staff need your support now more than ever.

This January, I'm kickstarting 2021 by taking part in Running off Christmas. I'll be running 31 miles throughout the month to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity (GOSH Charity). After all the festivities and with the cold and wet weather January can bring, your donations to support Great Ormond Street Hospital's life saving work will keep me going when I need it most.

It's quick, easy and secure to donate, just press the Give Now button!

GOSH's patients, families and staff need your support now more than ever.

charity.name: Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity
story:
As most of you will know, i was hugely thankful for your donations a few years ago when i ran for the sick childrens trust, this time round i am raising money for Great Ormond street hospital. Without this fantastic hospital my little Daisy wouldn't be here now. Daisy had 2 open heart surgeries at GOSH in 2015 to fix 3 holes in her heart. Her first surgery was an emergency operation to attached PA band around one of her artery's to slow to flow of blood pumping into her lungs, Because her lungs were getting too much fluid she found breathing very difficult and a lot of the time she needed extra oxygen to help her breath.
The second surgery was in November 2015 to fill her hole in her heart. this was a complete success and she has been able to live a normal happy childhood ever since

This January, I'm kickstarting 2021 by taking part in Running off Christmas. the challenge is to run 31 miles in 31 days however i have set myself the challenge to run 93 miles in 31 days to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity (GOSH Charity). After all the festivities and with the cold and wet weather January can bring, your donations to support Great Ormond Street Hospital's life saving work will keep me going when I need it most. It's quick, easy and secure to donate, just press the Give Now button! GOSH's patients, families and staff need your support now more than ever.

pageSummary: Running 31 miles because To raise money for the amazing people at GOSH
pageSummaryWhy: To raise money for the amazing people at GOSH
story: Hello everyone, hope you're all keeping safe and well! In January, I will be raising money for GOSH by running 31 miles in a month (trying to run at least). As most of you know, Jacob was a born with a cleft lip, and the amazing doctors and nurses done an absolutely fantastic job on him. I'm hoping to raise as much money as I can for them, as a token of my appreciation for what they done, and continue to do for him. I know times are tough and money is tight, but if you could spare anything, no matter how big or small, it would be a huge help towards my target. In the words of Tesco 'Every Little Helps'. Thank you, you fine people.

story:
Our son was diagnosed with Acute Lymphoblastic Leukaemia in April 2020. Fourteen weeks after his baby
sister was born. It’s been a difficult seven months and a roller coaster of emotion.
We are so grateful, humbled and feel very lucky to have the treatment and support that Great Ormond Street has given us.

This January, I'm kickstarting 2021 by taking part in Running off Christmas. I'll be running 31 miles throughout the month to raise money for Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity (GOSH Charity). After all the festivities and with the cold and wet weather January can bring, your donations to support Great Ormond Street Hospital's life saving work will keep me going when I need it most.

It's quick, easy and secure to donate, just press the Give Now button!

GOSH's patients, families and staff need your support now more than ever.

pageSummary: I am running the Brighton marathon in Sept 2021 because seriously poorly children deserve a better future!
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the Brighton marathon in Sept 2021
pageSummaryWhy: seriously poorly children deserve a better future!
story:
Every day 618 children and young people arrive at Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH), where medical professionals battle the most complex illnesses. This extraordinary hospital has always depended on charitable support to give seriously ill children the best chance to fulfill their potential. 

Now that I have two gorgeous and healthy boys, I can fully understand the heartbreak it must cause to both the children and their parents when GOSH is needed. If me running a measly 26 miles will help in any way, I'm willing to do it! 

Thank you so much for visiting my justgiving page. Whether you decide to donate £1 or £50, the money we raise together will have a direct impact on the lives of children who DO deserve a better future!

pageSummaryWhat: I’m doing a mix of different video game challenges
pageSummaryWhy: its a good cause and I would like to help if  I ca
story:
Im geeking out for GOSH and taking on a gaming challenge to raise money for the seriously ill children,  their families and the NHS staff at Great Ormond Street Hospital. 

As GOSH plays a role in the national response to the COVID-19 crisis by treating more children from hospitals across London, resources will become increasingly stretched.   

The hospital needs the support of Great Ormond Street Hospital Children's Charity (GOSH Charity) now more than ever, so it can continue to deliver the best, life-saving care for seriously ill children. 

Your support will help keep me going when things get tough and give me the power-up I need to complete this challenge. Its quick, easy and secure to donate, just press the give now button on the right.

pageSummary: Sam and I are going to put ourselves through agony because 2021 need some good news and sanity
pageSummaryWhat: Sam and I are going to put ourselves through agony
pageSummaryWhy: 2021 need some good news and sanity
story:
With all the struggles 2020 had brought, Sam and I decided to take 2021 in our stride and focus on a challenge neither of us had ever considered. 

The London Triathlon seemed like a great opportunity to raise awareness for a great cause, while putting ourselves through hours of torture.

Our chosen charity relies on £100m a year from fundraising so that they can support the lives of 100s of children daily.

Taking place on Sunday 8th August 2021 we have over half a year to prepare ourselves mentally... and more importantly physically.

Thank you everyone who supports us and the Great Ormands Street Hospital children’s charity!

pageSummary: I am running the Brighton Marathon because of the life changing operations I received.
pageSummaryWhat: I am running the Brighton Marathon
pageSummaryWhy: of the life changing operations I received.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am running the Brighton Marathon on the 12th September 2021 in aid of Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) Charity. 

When I was born I had two life-changing issues. The first was that one of my nasal passages did not form and was blocked by bone. The other being my lungs had a limited flow of blood to them.

After spending the first few weeks of my life in the Special Care Baby Unit, neither of these issues had been identified. It wasn't until a year later and several trips to the hospital that the issues were finally diagnosed.

At three years old I was old enough to be operated on and my parents were able to get me referred to GOSH. I underwent several operations to clear my nose and a complex operation that fed a tiny coil from my thigh, through my heart and dropped at a point that forced the blood flow through my lungs.

Compared to the other incredible operations and work that everyone at GOSH does, these can seem like minor pieces of work. However, these operations changed my life and I will always be grateful. With my parents supporting GOSH every year I finally wanted to do my part to support them. I hope you can join me in supporting them by contributing to the amazing work they do.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

My partner Peter Mckenna is running in the half marathon for Great Ormond Street Hospital to raise money for sick children. Our son Ralph has been receiving treatment at Great Ormond Street since he was born. Ralph was born with a rare heart condition and needed heart surgery to save his life. After his 6 hour operation he's recovering very well. Peter will be running in aid of our son and to help other sick children in the future.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

For the last 41 years, a group of friends and members of Sapcote churches have sung carols around the streets to raise money for Cancer Research UK. This is not possible this year, but we feel it is important to continue to raise money for Cancer Research UK in this particularly difficult time. Many people's lives are touched by the effects of cancer, and this charity does amazing work in research and support which produces wonderful outcomes and gives hope to all.If you are able to donate any amount, small or large, that would be wonderful.

eventName: I'm a Golfer Get Me Out Of here
pageSummary: We are raising funds because they played such a vital role to families lives.
pageSummaryWhy: they played such a vital role to families lives.
story:
David and I are going to be taking part in a 72 hole golf challenge, this will be taking place at Abergele Golf Club within the grounds of the 'Im A Celebrity' castle in North Wales.

The challenge will take place on 2nd December 2020.

We have to decided to complete the challenge as over the course of 2020 it has been difficult to raise funds for charities with everything thats happened with COVID lockdowns. Cancer research UK is a charity along with St Kentigern's Hospice and Marie Curie that have suffered from reduced donations this year.

All of these charities are close to David and I, the support they have provided both of our families is amazing. We are also aware of how many of us are effected by Cancer and want to show our support as it touches so many of us each and every day.

Please show your support and donate.

Thank you.

Starting Monday 23rd November I’ll attempt to run 100 miles over the course of the week in celebration of my mums life and to raise money In her memory for Cancer Research UK. It’s 9 years ago this week that I lost mum to cancer. 

As my run is part of Centurion Running’s One Community event, my entry fee has already gone towards raising funds for MIND and NHS Together charities. .

charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 1089464, Scotland SC041666
story:
“Right now there are almost 3 million people living with cancer in the UK. This is set to grow to 4 million by 2030, and we face a future where 1 in 2 of us will be diagnosed at some point in our lives.“ - Macmillan Cancer Support.

My mother is currently suffering with stage 2 breast cancer and is due to have her second operation. The complications related to the operations and consequent chemotherapy has  been devastating for her and our whole family. Cancer takes a toll on both a persons physical and emotional well-being. It is a tragedy. That is what WE need to change.

As a Masters of Pharmacy student I am aware of the current limitations modern cancer medicines have. If only we had more research being put into finding an effective treatment; countless people would not have to compromise their quality of life. If we had more research to help us establish the causes of cancer; then we can help prevent people developing cancer. 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

pageSummary: I am participating in a 24 hour live stream because I want to make a difference.
pageSummaryWhat: I am participating in a 24 hour live stream
pageSummaryWhy: I want to make a difference.
story:
My name is Samuel Best.

Cancer has been an ever present menace in and around my families lives for as long as I can remember. In my immediate family no less than 5 family members and numerous friends have suffered through this disease. Some fighting until their heart-breaking passing. I have always wanted to help make a difference.

In my own personal nightmare, I've been given a chance to do this. After a year of struggling, I am due to have a full knee reconstruction. With the world how it is currently, I have to isolate before my surgery to ensure I avoid COVID. I have decided to use this time to make the difference I have always wanted to. Therefore I am committing to a 24 hour gaming live stream in order to raise much needed funds for Cancer Research UK, please donate anything you possibly can and join me in making a difference. Every donation saves lives. Lets get to £500... and maybe more!

Thankyou

eventName: In memory of Santokben Lakhamshi Shah
pageSummary: FUNDRAISING because we lost our beloved Mum through cancer
pageSummaryWhy: we lost our beloved Mum through cancer
story:
Our beloved mum, grandma and great-grandma (fondly known as Baa) left us on 3rd November 2020 after losing her battle with cancer.

Always with a smiling face and calm nature, our Baa will be dearly missed. Her resilience in the face of adversity, strong-will, generosity and kindness to those all around her were unparalleled.
Baa’s love of life, of people and of good food made her a joy to be with. Wonderful memories of Baa will stay in our hearts forever. 

To honour Baa's memory, please kindly consider a donation to Cancer Research UK whose work is dedicated to saving lives through research. Not only is early diagnosis and treatment vital in enabling people with cancer to get better, but by raising money for research, we can bring about the day they say, "There's a cure for cancer!" 

Remember to give Gift Aid, as it does make a huge difference.

Thank-you!

pageSummary: I am cycling 1000km from Muscat to Salalah because I am fundraising in memory of Roger Bristow.
pageSummaryWhat: I am cycling 1000km from Muscat to Salalah
pageSummaryWhy: I am fundraising in memory of Roger Bristow.
story:
I have been planning to cycle from Salalah to Muscat for almost a year.  The ride was supposed to have taken place in March of this year but was postponed due to the COVID 19 lockdown here in Oman. 

 Due to quarantine restrictions here in Oman and the UK I will not be able to travel to the UK at Christmas and have decided to complete the ride in the Christmas Holidays,  though due to the change in prevailing winds it  will now be from Muscat to Salalah. a distance of 1,000 kilometres. 

The ride will take 7 days to complete and will involve riding an average of 150km a day.

With Roger passing away in September, I have decided to use the trip to highlight the work and raise money for Cancer Reserach.

I hope you will enjoy following my trip and can support this worthy cause at the same time.

pageSummary: Raising Money to Save Life because everyone deserve a happy life.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

We have divided the Argyll Club into seven geographical clusters, and each team has hand-picked a local charity close to their location, and close to our heart.

We have proudly chosen to support Cancer Research UK, who fund scientist, doctor, and nurses to undertake life-saving research that will help us to beat cancer sooner. 

2020 has been tough for everyone. Especially those who are being affected by cancers and Covid-19. We are hoping that by supporting this charity we can help saving life and preventing families who have to face losing their love ones. 

#loveforlondon

pageSummary: I have set up this page in memory of my Mum. because She was 1 year post lung cancer free.
pageSummaryWhat: I have set up this page in memory of my Mum.
pageSummaryWhy: She was 1 year post lung cancer free.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I set this page up as, even though my Mum loved flowers especially roses, she would have preferred a donation to Cancer research. She had lung cancer last year. She had to have 30% of her lung taken away. It worked and they got all of the cancer. Which meant she didn’t have to have further treatment. Unfortunately we lost Mum 12th November to another horrible condition. 

If you can give anything we would be very grateful. 

Rest in peace my dear Mum xx

pageSummary: We are family of Usha/ Millie and are fundraising because of the impact cancer has on millions of lives
pageSummaryWhat: We are family of Usha/ Millie and are fundraising
pageSummaryWhy: of the impact cancer has on millions of lives
story:
22 September 1951 – 20 November 2020


Urmila/Usha/Millie Luhar

It is with deep sadness that we announce Urmila Luhar, our dear mother and wife passed away peacefully on Friday 20 November 2020.

Urmila was strong willed, pure of heart, with the most beautiful smile. She will be greatly missed by everyone she touched. Compassion radiated from her wherever she stood. We are thankful to our relatives and friends for all their support through this difficult time and we will forever be grateful for the happy memories she leaves with us.

‘You can shed tears that she is gone or you can smile because she has lived an inspiring life’

Savita Baa, Mahendra, Jignesh, Chetna, Nilesh and Shivani,

pageSummary: Running 5km a day, every day in December because now, more than ever, they need our support
pageSummaryWhat: Running 5km a day, every day in December
pageSummaryWhy: now, more than ever, they need our support
story:
The picture at the top of this page was taken 5 and a half years ago. You wouldn’t know it at the time, but both of my Parents were going through treatment for Cancer. Having been diagnosed around a month apart in the Spring, my Dad for a GIST (a form of stomach cancer) and my Mum for Breast Cancer.

I’ve wanted to do something for a long time to raise funds for a charity who dedicate their work to finding cures for all cancers.

This December I’ll be taking part in the annual ‘Marcothon’ running 5km/day every day of the month. I’m not a runner, but looking forward to the challenge.

This year, in 2020, we are seeing early signs recently that with enormous resource, science can find solutions to what seem initially unbeatable enemies. Applying the same logic to Cancer, we must double in our resolve to raise funds to further research so that one day a cure for all forms of cancer is a reality.

Please give as little or as much as you can. You can follow my daily runs on Strava, Twitter and Instagram.

story: In September 2020 I lost my Mum to Cancer , the biggest surprise was that 5 weeks prior to losing she was in perfect health . Scary as this is the same happened to Matthew our Transport Manager who lost his dad in a 5 weeks time frame. It was a wake up call for me that Cancer can take people so quickly , some thing that I had no previous comprehension of . Part of CV19 lock down encouraged all of the team at Rexel Leeds to get fit a challenge that they succeeded in losing a combined 10 Stone in 13 weeks. Because the team are still in there top physical peak ...........well kind of!!! I have challenged my work colleagues to travel the distance from Rexel Leeds to Mums old house in Altea Spain starting 1st of December through to the 18th of December . Some good people having a laugh working together and ending up in Spain ..... No better way of remembering my mum

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit the Financial Control JustGiving page.

We will be aiming to walk, run or cycle from Watford to the North Pole (2,650 miles) in December to raise money for Cancer Research UK for Children & Young People.

If you are a participant of the challenge, we suggest a minimum donation of £10. 

Please ask your friends and family to also support you during your challenge.

We aim to arrive to start our challenge on the 30th of November. We will be (virtually) leaving our Watford Head Office on this day and hope to arrive at The North Pole by the 23rd of December. Please help support us on our journey.

story:
Thank you for visiting the fund page. We have made this fund to raise money towards cancer research, more specifically to CANCER RESEARCH UK.
Cancer is sadly a disease that kills millions of people every, more specifically 9.6 million deaths due to cancer in 2018.
Scientists are working really hard to find a cure to cancer and to save the lives of these millions of people everyday. In a lot of countries though, the government does not give enough money to do so and so this is where scientists ask for our help.
All the donations will go towards possibly saving lives every year and so every penny counts. Scientists need your help!

eventName: Lozzy's RWB 750 miles Triathlon in 9 months
story:
Hi my name is Lauren Mcwhinnie and I'm 22 years old. Earlier this year I set myself the goal to "Run 500 miles across 6 months." Unfortunately; it hasn't planned out that way. As 3 months has allready passed and I've missed being part of fundraising events and helping other people.    I gave up running a while back as I was struggling through internal health, but am hopeful I'll be back to running again soon.

Therefore; I decided to set myself this new Virtual fundraising event!                                                                                           #Run 250 miles - completed with £596 raised and sent to charity  #Walk 250 miles  - currently                                                          #Bike 250 miles  - next year 

In the hope of the long-term I can get more people to support and sponsor my event.                                                    As me and my family lost our Grandma earlier this year in May time.  Previously; another of our family member's was diagnosed with Skin type 2 cancer this year also.                    These are two people who are inspirational to me !!

It would be lovely at the end of the 9 months goal if I can give as much money raised to "Cancer Research UK" to fund for life-threatening diseases, to help find a cure and early diagnosis to save lives and help those families in need, through difficult times and this pandemic. Thankyou x

pageSummary: I am growing a beard. because I wanted to do something positive during lockdown
pageSummaryWhy: I wanted to do something positive during lockdown
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Anyone who knows me well, knows that I’ve never had a beard. I’ve tried on several occasions to grow one, but I haven’t been able to get past the 2 week itching phase.

So, from the start of lockdown on Thursday 5th of November I’m going to abstain from shaving and attempt to grow a beard for at least the 4 weeks of lockdown.

In order to stop me from succumbing to the itch, I’m asking my friends and family to make a donation to Cancer Research UK to try to do my bit to mitigate the immense damage being done to cancer care and detection due to Covid-19.

So if you want to see me with a beard and make some money for a good cause, then please pledge a few pennies

pageSummary: I am walking 251169 steps in 30days to raise money because I wish my mum was here to meet her grandchildren
pageSummaryWhat: I am walking 251169 steps in 30days to raise money
pageSummaryWhy: I wish my mum was here to meet her grandchildren
story:
I have set myself a challenge to walk 251169 steps in 30 days. The random number of steps was actually my mum’s date of birth, and as Christmas was our favourite time of the year I decided it was only fitting that the challenge started on her day (25th November) and ended on our favourite day (25th December). 

I am currently on maternity leave with my amazing baby girl, MIa Jane so we will be clocking up the steps together. We will walk/jog/run everyday in memory of my mum to raise money in the hope that Cancer Research can continue their great work in the big fight against cancer and strive to give the gift of life. 

I have already got some regular walking buddies but if you’re in the Yeovil area and fancy some socially distanced company for a walk/jog/run let us know and we will see what we can do. 

I have 647 friends on here so I’m setting my target at £647. I am asking for you to please donate £1 and share this post and see how much we can raise together. 

I will try my hardest to post updates on our daily activities making every step count. 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummary: I am doing a skydive because I want to raise awareness of a illness and charity
pageSummaryWhy: I want to raise awareness of a illness and charity
story:
As many of my friends and family know we were struck with utter shocker of losing my beautiful Nan so suddenly back in august. My nan was Strong, courageous and completely selfless in every way ;a true inspiration to everyone . She has always been my biggest fan and could make every wrong sticky situation right for me with just a few words and a hug.

This time last year me and my Nan were chatting away as we usually did in an evening and I explained how much I was scared of heights but how next year was going to be a year of saying yes to everything so in my Nans true good humour she gifted me a skydive for Christmas 2019. So here I am doing the dive in February ( left it as late as I possibly could) in memory of her and also to raise some money to fight this awful gruelling illness. 

So here’s to My Nan My mum and so much more !!

pageSummary: In memory of what Helen's (mum's) 70th Birthday because we want others to see many more birthday's to come
pageSummaryWhat: In memory of what Helen's (mum's) 70th Birthday
pageSummaryWhy: we want others to see many more birthday's to come
story:
Friday 20 November 2020 would of been Mum's  70th Birthday, we were lucky enough to spend her 60th with close friends and family before she sadly passed away a few months later to ovarian cancer.   Those of you who met mum, knew of her thirst for life, her wicked sense of humour and her  kindness for others.  

Therefore, to celebrate her birthday we want to support a charity who is doing something to change things - through research into new treatments and better diagnosis.  Since mum's death cancer has gone on to affect other members of our family and our hope is that by investing in research others and their families get to celebrate their 70th birthdays together.  

Please raise a G & T to a very special lady on 20 November....she is gone but never far from our thoughts!  We miss you!!

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

As you will probably be aware, our wonderful mother, grandmother and great grandmother, passed away on Saturday 14th November 2020. She was adored by us all and will be greatly missed.  Jean was a kind and loving lady, who touched the hearts of everyone that she met.

Jean was married to her husband Basil for 61 years and spent most of her life in Eastern Green in Coventry.  Two years ago, she moved to Rectory Court Care Home, in South London to be near to her daughter, grandchildren and five great grandchildren. 

Funds are being raised for Cancer Research UK as Jean was diagnosed with Bowel Cancer over 10 years ago and never complained even through the difficult times.  Jean lost both her husband and son to cancer, but was always a pillar of strength to those around her.

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. Call me crazy but I wanted to challenge myself to accomplish something that I would consider to be almost impossible. I'm not a runner; never have been, never will be. But, I keep trying and I thought I would give it another go to help raise some money before my 40th birthday in December. Doing the job I do, I'm always on my feet but I don't really do half as much exercise as I should be due to the long hours and time spent marking and planning. So, starting on November 24th, I have given myself 1 month to run/walk/jog/crawl 40km (not all in one go - that really is impossible) to raise funds for a charity that, as many of you will know, is very very close to my heart. ❤ It will also give me the motivation I need to make time for some much-needed exercise. 

I thank you in advance for any donations and look forward to achieving my goal (and possibly more) by Christmas. Wish me luck!

eventName: ACC Shavers - Long locks cut to the floor
pageSummary: We are all shaving our heads because we want to raise awareness for ACC and support Lin
pageSummaryWhat: We are all shaving our heads
pageSummaryWhy: we want to raise awareness for ACC and support Lin
story: 15 years ago Lin was diagnosed with a very rare form of cancer called Adrenocortical Carcinoma – ACC for short.  Following the removal of a 25cm tumour and sizable re-sectioning a solid recovery was made.  As a family we put this behind us and thought no more about it, thinking this horrible disease had been beaten.  Alas 2 years ago ACC returned in Lin’s lung.  More significant surgery cleared another big tumour, and more surgery to clear additional complications.  A course of Mitotane ‘chemo’ has been underway for 18 months and through that time a further 3 lung tumours and one subcutaneous tumour have been ‘dealt with’.  With another lung and another subcutaneous tumour yet to be removed; Lin has started additional aggressive IV Chemo called EDP, it's a blend of 3 chemos administered over 4 days, monthly for 6 months.  Cold caps have helped many to keep their hair through chemo, but on this occasion it won’t work and hair loss is about to happen.  Josh, Lottie and I have decided we’re going to join the gang and shave our heads when Lin loses her hair.  A moment of family solidarity as we head into winter.  We’re sure it’ll raise attention as we do and hope it brings greater awareness of ACC as we try to raise some money for Cancer Research UK which supports patients, and research among its aims.  If any of you have noticed a blip in stocks associated with hats, I can confidently assure you Lin has only just started!  We’re getting our razors sharpened and will post some pics when Lottie’s long locks and Josh and my shorter mops are gone.
title: Dom, Josh and Lottie's ACC Shavers - Long locks cut to the floor

story:
Instead of cards or presents this year I’m asking friends and family to donate to cancer research instead. 

All charities have been hit hard by Covid and it was so difficult choosing just one. Cancer research strikes a personal chord with me though, through having already lost people to it and especially this year knowing family and close friends are going through it. It doesn’t affect just one person, it affects everyone who loves that person. So for all the people I love who have been and are affected by cancer, this birthday I would like to raise money to help all those working hard to find treatments to beat it. 

I’m also mindful of how Covid has hit families hard too so please don’t feel any pressure to donate. 

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.
