story: In September 2020 I lost my Mum to Cancer , the biggest surprise was that 5 weeks prior to losing she was in perfect health . Scary as this is the same happened to Matthew our Transport Manager who lost his dad in a 5 weeks time frame. It was a wake up call for me that Cancer can take people so quickly , some thing that I had no previous comprehension of . Part of CV19 lock down encouraged all of the team at Rexel Leeds to get fit a challenge that they succeeded in losing a combined 10 Stone in 13 weeks. Because the team are still in there top physical peak ...........well kind of!!! I have challenged my work colleagues to travel the distance from Rexel Leeds to Mums old house in Altea Spain starting 1st of December through to the 18th of December . Some good people having a laugh working together and ending up in Spain ..... No better way of remembering my mum

story:
On Friday 13th November, our friend and colleague Bill McDowall, also known as Mr Mac by all of our children, sadly lost his battle with cancer. 

Mr Mac worked at Catchgate Primary School for 10 years. In this time, he put a smile on everyone's face on a daily basis.  He is going to be a huge miss to all of the staff and children within our school and we will always remember the memories made with him.

In memory of Mr Mac, we would like to raise some money to go to a charity close to the family's hearts. Any donation towards the Cancer Research charity will be greatly appreciated. 

Thank you,

From all staff and children of Catchgate  Primary School

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

We are taking part in a cross country competition, which is part of Mid-Sussex Active School Games. Due to the Race for Life event we had planned for July 2020 being cancelled, we are using this event as a way to raise money for Cancer Research instead. 

Year 5 and 6 children will be running a 1.5km race, Year 3 and 4 will run 1km and Key Stage 1 will be running two laps of the course. For every child that completes the course, they will receive a Race for Life medal! 

The top 5 girls an top 5 boys from each year group, will have their results entered in the wider county competition.

pageSummary: We are Running a Marathon In a Santa hat
pageSummaryWhat: We are Running a Marathon In a Santa hat
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

We will be running a Marathon on The 5th of December in Santa hats to raise money for Cancer Research. We hope the money raised will help the fight against cancer, and improve the lives of those affected by cancer. Any Donation of any amount would be appreciated.

Thank you, 

Ben and Jack

pageSummary: Instead of a 'collection', please help raise money because this one affects us all!
pageSummaryWhat: Instead of a 'collection', please help raise money
story:
I am being extremely presumptuous here... but it comes with experience of Bowbrook! Now is not the right time for leaving collections, we all have more than enough to think about and times are incredibly challenging. I am hoping this opportunity is less onerous... 

I have had the great joy of being part of the Bowbrook picture for 16, oops, sixteen years and have watched it grow and grow and grow. It is now time for me to begin a new chapter, with mixed emotions. I am currently training for an exciting new role in schools, as a School Business Manager which will be completed in January 2022; my own business finally has a full-time MD but overshadowing this exciting time, is my incredible father, Rev. Philip Auden DL MNM, who is fighting his way with terminal cancer and has only months to live. My Dad and I have been through so much together, more than most fathers and sons I'd say, and I feel it is my duty to be with him at this time. My Mum also succumbed to this horrible disease at a relatively early age and I know in talking to you, the glorious parents over the years, some of you have your own life experiences with this wretched disease. I have been supporting  Cancer Research for many years and I feel the greater the opportunity they have to find those elusive cures, the brighter the future will look.  My target, represents ten pounds for each year I have been associated with Bowbrook (try and work that one out...) plus of course, 300 is a special number for me, for the eagle-eyed car- spotters amongst you. 

THANK YOU (a big thank you...) to my awesome colleagues, my many friends, to your fabulous children, to you the parents (past and present) for making my journey at Bowbrook incredibly memorable, and one special, heartfelt thank you to Mr and Mrs Allen, without whom none of this, in fact any of it, would be possible for any of us! With deepest thanks to you all, James / Mr Auden/Mr A.

pageSummary: Friday 11th December - Spread a little cheer!
pageSummaryWhat: Friday 11th December - Spread a little cheer!
story:
Hello All,

Lets face it, it's not been a good year!  So to spread a little cheer I invite all colleagues in the GWR West Region to support Cancer Research UK by wearing a Christmas Jumper on Friday 11th December 2020 and donating a little cash to this worthwhile cause.

I am sure you all know someone who has been affected by cancer and the work that Cancer Research UK do is vital to improve treatment and save lives.

So please give a little or a lot and proudly wear your crazy Christmas jumpers for the day!

Thanks for reading! 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

eventName: Hazza and Sully run the UK - Virtually
story:
Covid-19 has not only gate-crashed our daily lives, but also stemmed valuable health treatments for the ones we love. Cancer Research is a charity that is close to us.

Our challenge is to run 1083 miles virtually from Land's End to John A'Groats by the time midnight strikes on Sunday 24th October 2021. All our data will be bona fide strava runs...no walks to the nursery, no dashes to the bathroom, no lashings of banter pacing the corridors. To add further spice, we started the official challenge late and there will be a gruelling punishment (ideas welcome) for the one that finishes last along with a £100 donation.

You can follow us on the live link below and to keep this wonderfully old-fashioned, we will posting classic "refreshment" stops along the way.

https://tinyurl.com/yyb97fve

Thank you.

Harry and Ian

pageSummary: Donation rather than secret Santa because ... why not?
story:
Hey! 

There were lots of options when making this page, sponsored walk, sponsored swim, skydive, perhaps we’ll re-visit the idea of a sponsored silence for some of you... But our way of doing things... is doing less!!! 

We love our secret Santa every year, but this year we’re just making donations. 

The usual secret Santa is £15 / £20 so... donate what you want.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.name: Cancer Research UK
charity.registrationNumber: in England and Wales 1089464, Scotland SC041666
pageSummary: Walking the Yorkshire three peaks because 2021 needs to be better than 2020!
story:
What are we doing: 

A group of amateur but enthusiastic walkers take on the Yorkshire three peaks........in January! 40 km, 5200 ft ascent in less than 12 hours.

Why are we doing it?

As 2020 has been a complete write off, we thought it would be great to kick off 2021 by personally challenging ourselves, whilst raising money for a good cause. Cancer research UK is a charity that is extremely close to the hearts of our team. Due to the current Covid restrictions many charities have seen a downturn in fundraising donations, we would like to do our small part to ensure that vital cancer research is still being carried out.

Who are we?

We are a team of six RAF colleagues based at RAF Odiham 18 (B) Sqn;

Karl Keens, Duncan Hill, Terry Robson, Tony Barnes, Ed Fisher and Kate Snelgrove.

How will Covid impact our challenge?

We are currently planning on walking on the 30th Jan, of course this date will be flexible depending on the emerging Covid restrictions.

How can you support us?

No matter how small the donation, every penny goes towards a great cause. Even if you are unable to make a donation, you can help us by sharing our page on social media.

eventName: Light Up Christmas for Marie Curie Nurses in Kent
story:
This year, we need local businesses and companies to come together to Light Up Christmas for Marie Curie’s Kent Nursing Service. We have an ambitious target of raising £7,020 which will fund the service for the 3 days of Christmas, meaning our Nurses can help the people they care for make the most of what could be their final Christmas with their loved ones.

By donating unused Christmas party funds, passing an e-card around or hosting a festive fundraising event with colleagues - you can make a huge difference to families living in your community.

Families like Helen’s

XXXX

We need you to come together with businesses and communities across Surrey to help us be there for many more families like Helen’s this Christmas. By helping us Light Up Christmas, you’ll ensure that our Nurses can be there for families who are facing their last one together.

There are two ways you can get involved and support the campaign.

Make a donation – simply click the donate button at the top. You may decide to donate what you would normally spend on a Christmas Party or Christmas cards.

Set up a JustGiving page for staff fundraising – we have lots of festive
fundraising ideas which we can share with you, and here are just a few examples

  • You could hold a virtual festive jumper day with a prize for the wackiest jumper or a ‘dec your desk’ competition, with a special ‘video call tea break’ for the judging to take place.
  • If your staff are working from home, you could suggest they donate the cost of their normal weekly commute, or the price of their morning coffee.

To thank you if you set up a JustGiving page or donating over £20 to our page we will:

  • Hang a tag with your company name or logo on the Christmas Tree that will go up in our Care Co-ordination Centre in Caterham (Surrey) in December, so our Nursing Team can see your support in-between patient visits. Once the campaign comes to an end, we’ll also share your support on Marie Curie’s South East social media pages.
  • Provide you with a choice of custom Christmas e-cards to send to your staff, customers, clients, suppliers and friends, encouraging them to support too.
  • Provide festive fundraising ideas.

Every penny donated or raised really will make a huge difference and help us Light Up Christmas for the Kent Nursing Service. Here are just a few examples of how the funds will help over the festive period:

  • £1 will put a pen torch in the pocket of a Marie Curie Nurse, so they can do vital examinations of the people in their care.
  • £20 will fund an hour of expert care and support for someone living with a terminal illness in the comfort of their own home over the Christmas period.
  • £180 will pay for a night shift for a Marie Curie Nurse so that the patient’s family can take a well-earned rest knowing their loved one is well looked after.
  • £540 will sponsor a Marie Curie nurse for the 3 days of Christmas.
  • £7,020 will fund the Kent Nursing Service for the 3 days of Christmas, meaning we can help families make the most of what could be their final Christmas together.

For more information or to get involved, please contact us on  07872 418098 or email florin.diaconu@mariecurie.org.uk

We really hope you will consider supporting our patients, their families and our Nurses this Christmas.

Thank you, and Merry Christmas!

eventName: Light Up Christmas for Marie Curie Nurses in Hampshire
story:
This year, we need local businesses and companies to come together to Light Up Christmas for Marie Curie’s Hampshire Nursing Service. We have an ambitious target of raising £10,000 which will fund the service for the 5 days of Christmas, meaning our Nurses can help the people they care for make the most of what could be their final Christmas with their loved ones. 

By donating unused Christmas party funds, passing an e-card around or hosting a festive fundraising event with colleagues - you can make a huge difference to families living in your community.

Families like Helen’s.

"My Father, Mick Yates, was diagnosed with bowel cancer in 2008. He underwent major operations and received intensive chemo and radiotherapy treatment. He made a remarkable recovery and was able to enjoy and get on with his life.

Sadly, in September 2019 he was informed he had developed secondary anal cancer. He made the decision to have an intense course of radiotherapy which really took its toll on him. He slowly began to improve and seemed to be getting stronger but over Christmas/New Year 2019 he became unwell. He had a DVT and had also developed an infection.

On January 16th I sat with Dad and Chriss (his Wife) while Doctors discussed his future treatment. The prognosis was not good, the cancer was spreading and the infection had taken hold. Dad made the extremely brave decision to decline any further treatment. His wish was that he wanted to go home to die but we were told it would take a number of days to get things in place and he may only have a few days once his treatment was stopped.

Dad surprised us all, as a week later he was still with us and even had discussions with the palliative care team about getting him home from hospital.

We started preparing for his homecoming on the 23rd January. It was a rushed and disorganised discharge but I was able to travel home with him in the ambulance that evening. I think I went through every emotion that afternoon/evening. Happy that Dad was finally getting out of hospital but heartbroken that I knew he was coming home to die. Would we manage? Was it the right decision? It was what Dad wanted so we had to be strong.

When he and I finally arrived home nearing 9pm, I was so pleased to be greeted by two happy faces who put an immediate calm on the situation, Stuart and Mandy from Marie Curie. They made Dad comfortable and settled him in bed. Both Stuart and Mandy were nearing the end of their shift but they stayed until the night sitter arrived and comforted and chatted to both Chriss and I.

Over the next 12 days there were many visits by the Marie Curie Nurses and Carers. Everyone was so caring and friendly and took their time, nothing was too much trouble.

Dad always dressed very smart and took a pride in his appearance. When he asked if he could be showered, have his hair washed, have a shave all his needs were met as best as could be under his deteriorating condition and every single carer went above and beyond to make him feel comfortable and relaxed. They also took the time to chat to the family and would happily discuss any concerns or questions we had. 

Bringing him home as he had wished was the right thing to do and we were able to spend some precious quality time together reminiscing the good times. He was able to sit and admire his fabulous view on a few occasions. Watch and listen to the birds in his garden and finally pass peacefully in the comfort of his own home on the 4th February 2020. We have Marie Curie to thank for that and I will always be grateful to the care that they gave to him." - Helen

We need you to come together with businesses and communities across Hampshire to help us be there for many more families like Helen’s this Christmas. By helping us Light Up Christmas, you’ll ensure that our Nurses can be there for families who might be facing their last one together.

There are two ways you can get involved and support the campaign.

Make a donation – simply click the donate button at the top. You may decide to donate what you would normally spend on a Christmas Party or Christmas cards.

Set up a JustGiving page for staff fundraising – create Christmas cheer amongst colleagues with some festive fundraising. We have lots of ideas which we can share with you, from 'caroloke' to a 'dec your desk' competition!

To thank you if you set up a JustGiving page or donating over £20 to our page we will:

  • Hang a decoration with your company name/logo on the Christmas Tree in our Care Co-ordination Centre in Fareham during December, so our Nursing Team can see your support in-between patient visits. We’ll also share your support on Marie Curie’s South East social media pages.
  • Provide you with a choice of custom Christmas e-cards to send to your staff, customers, clients, suppliers and friends, encouraging them to support too.
  • Provide festive fundraising ideas.

Every penny donated or raised really will make a huge difference and help us Light Up Christmas for the Hampshire Nursing Service. Here are just a few examples of how the funds will help over the festive period:

  • £1 will put a pen torch in the pocket of a Marie Curie Nurse, so they can do vital examinations of the people in their care.
  • £20 will fund an hour of expert care and support for someone living with a terminal illness in the comfort of their own home over the Christmas period.
  • £180 will pay for a night shift for a Marie Curie Nurse so that the patient’s family can take a well-earned rest knowing their loved one is well looked after.
  • £240 will sponsor a Marie Curie team of nurses caring and offering support during the day for patients  
  • £10,000 will fund the Hampshire Nursing Service for the 5 days of Christmas, meaning we can help families make the most of what could be their final Christmas together.

For more information or to get involved, please contact us on  07872 418098 or email florin.diaconu@mariecurie.org.uk

We really hope you will consider supporting our patients, their families and our Nurses this Christmas.

Thank you, and Merry Christmas!

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
charity.registrationNumber: 207994 (England & Wales) and SC038731 (Scotland)
eventName: Light Up Christmas for Marie Curie Rapid Response Nurses - Lewisham & Bromley
owner: Marie Curie Rapid Response Service - London
pageSummary: We are lighting up Christmas because families are facing their last Christmas together
pageSummaryWhy: families are facing their last Christmas together
story:
Help us to Light up Christmas for families who are facing their final Christmas with their loved ones - families like Dawn's:

'This meant that David got to spend his last Christmas and New year at home, surrounded by his family. He passed away peacefully on 5 January 2018 with me, Charlotte and Christopher by his side -
just like I’d always promised him.'

Marie Curie Nurses made this important promise possible - Dawn explains:

My husband David was first diagnosed with a stage 4 glioblastoma on 14 October 2016 but he didn’t have any symptoms at first. Then on 2 October 2017 I took David to the doctor as he had pulled a muscle in his shoulder. The doctor said that David was looking extremely well and to keep doing what he was doing. When David stood up to leave he mentioned that he had a tingling in his right foot. We were sent to hospital for a scan and on the 4 October 2017 we received the news that David had Leptomengial Spread. His spinal cord was completely covered in tumours, and he was given 3 months to live. David started to lose his coordination in December, and his condition declined very rapidly. 

Marie Curie nurses started to call with David and he always said, ‘don’t worry about me, there is always somebody else a lot worse off’. I worried that the presence of the Marie Curie nurses would panic him, but they were all so lovely and caring, that he felt at ease. We connected with Sandra in particular, she always gave us a hug when she arrived. A few of the Marie Curie nurses said they could feel the warmth and love in our home when they arrived, which was a lovely thing to hear.

From Boxing Day onwards, David was bed bound and sleeping in the family room downstairs. We never went to bed. All three of us would lay on the sofas next to him, or pull up a chair and rest our feet on his bed, holding hands and watching Christmas TV while he slept. But when Sandra came, she made us go to bed, even just for a few hours, while she watched over David and managed his pain when required. As he became weaker, Sandra and the other Marie Curie nurses were amazing and helped us look after him. 

'This meant that David got to spend his last Christmas and New year at home, surrounded by his family. He passed away peacefully on 5 January 2018 with me, Charlotte and Christopher by his side - just like I’d always promised him.'

It was exactly as he wanted – and it was thanks in part to the support and care of the Marie Curie nurses

Our Rapid Response Nurses provide care at home so that those facing their last Christmas can be surrounded by loved ones and their carers can get the rest and peace of mind that they need in the final days.

Our Rapid Response Team can respond to patients in the community, within an hour of their call, to manage their care and prevent unnecessary hospital admissions. Right now, more people need us than ever before. 

With events still cancelled and larger public gatherings on ice, much of our fundraising is still on hold. We still urgently need support. It is crucial we are there for the people who need us, those living with illnesses
including cancer, dementia and motor neurone disease. We are also now directly supporting patients with coronavirus. We also need to ensure that all our Nurses and Healthcare Assistants have sufficient PPE to keep themselves and their patients safe.

There is an increased need for our services, and it is vital we can continue to be there and working in the best way for the people who need us and to ensure that those facing their last Christmas can do so in their own homes, surrounded by loved ones.

Your support can help us to Light up Christmas for those families in need in the following ways:

£1 will put a pen torch in the pocket of a Marie Curie Nurse so they can do vital examinations

£20 will fund an hour of care for someone with a terminal illness in the comfort of their own home

£29 will keep the local Care Co-ordination Centre running for an hour

£180 will fund a night shift for a Nurse so a patient's family can take a well-earned rest knowing their loved one is well looked after

£1,600 will sponsor a Marie Curie Nurse for the 12 days of Christmas

*please note all photos were taken pre-COVID

£20 will fund an hour of care for someone with a terminal illness in the comfort of their own home

£29 will keep the local Care Co-ordination Centre running for an hour

£180 will fund a night shift for a Nurse so a patient's family can take a well-earned rest knowing their loved one is well looked after

£1,600 will sponsor a Marie Curie Nurse for the 12 days of Christmas

*please note all photos were taken pre-COVID

charity.name: Marie Curie
charity.registrationNumber: 207994 (England & Wales) and SC038731 (Scotland)
pageSummary: I am raising money because everyone deserves the best care when they need it
pageSummaryWhy: everyone deserves the best care when they need it
story:
My wife Katie is a doctor at Marie Curie and so this is a very important cause for us both. She has seen first hand the difference the hospice makes to so many patients. This Christmas,  Marie Curie need local businesses and people to donate anything they can to help people with terminal illnesses. Every single day at the hospice is an extraordinary day. And every moment is precious. The hospice nurses, doctors and therapists provide the best possible care for people with serious illnesses, and offer vital emotional support for them and their families. The hospice is a warm, welcoming place where loved ones can be together in peaceful surroundings and in as much comfort as possible. Whether it's for one day or several weeks, the time people spend at the hospice is precious, and is cherished by them and their families.

Know the impact of your donations. We need to raise:

£57.75 to provide home cooked hot meals for one patient for the week

£136.00 to keep the lights on for one day

£214.50 to provide home cooked hot meals on Christmas Day to all our patients

£9,678.00 every single day to run all our services at the Hospice


During COVID it has been a difficult time for the hospice and their patients and we would be very grateful for anything you can donate to help the hospice in Hampstead.

eventName: Kitsch in Sync singing for Marie Curie
pageSummary: Singing virtually because normally we would be at station bucket collections
pageSummaryWhy: normally we would be at station bucket collections
story:
At this time of year Kitsch in Sync would normally be donning our yellow Marie Curie santa hats and singing to help raise money to fund vital end of life care at various stations across London.

This year we have had to do this virtually!  We have created a festive video of us singing!  If you have enjoyed our performance then please donate to this very worthy cause.

Over the past year, dying has become a front-of-mind issue for us all. The pandemic and our ageing population means it’s never been more pressing to make sure we have the right care and support in place to be able to protect and cherish each other as we reach the final months, weeks, days and hours of our lives.

Marie Curie is here to support everyone in the UK through all aspects of dying, death and bereavement – and to fight for a society where everyone gets to have the best experience possible at the end of their lives. We support the NHS by providing frontline care. We provide vital bereavement support for family and friends. And we help the nation prepare for death, to help makes things better at the end.

Last year we helped more than 60,000 people directly and reached over two million more. Marie Curie Nurses care for people in their homes,
giving much-needed respite to overstretched carers. Our nine hospices offer the reassurance of specialist care and support in a friendly, welcoming environment – so people can feel safe and cared-for in their final months, weeks and days of life. Our trusted information and support line help people in their hour of need to feel reassured, informed and empowered to face what’s happening in their lives. Our campaigns influence decision-makers so people whose lives are touched by terminal illness, death and bereavement have a voice advocating for the change they need to see. 

Marie Curie couldn't do this without the support of people like you

£2 pays for a glass of wine for a patient at one of our hospices, because enjoying a favourite tipple brings a smile to people’s faces and is a treat many look forward to.

£3 pays for someone staying in a hospice to enjoy a delicious, nourishing meal.

£20 pays for an hour of expert care and emotional support for someone living with a terminal illness, in the comfort of their own home.

£25 pays for a bereavement counsellor to listen, soothe and support someone who’s grieving for an hour.

£32 pays for a call to our Support Line, meaning someone in need can pick up the phone and receive practical information and emotional support.

£41 kits out a Marie Curie Nurse, so they’re ready to face anything with a smile and the sense of pride that their uniform brings.

Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummary: We are raising funds because they played such a vital role to families lives.
pageSummaryWhy: they played such a vital role to families lives.
story:
David and I are going to be taking part in a 72 hole golf challenge, this will be taking place at Abergele Golf Club within the grounds of the 'Im A Celebrity' castle in North Wales.

The challenge will take place on 2nd December 2020.

We have to decided to complete the challenge as over the course of 2020 it has been difficult to raise funds for charities with everything thats happened with COVID lockdowns. Cancer research UK is a charity along with St Kentigern's Hospice and Marie Curie that have suffered from reduced donations this year.

All of these charities are close to David and I, the support they have provided both of our families is amazing. We are also aware of how many of us are effected by Cancer and want to show our support as it touches so many of us each and every day.

Please show your support and donate to either charity or all of them.

Thank you

eventName: Marie Curie 12ks of Christmas - David's Knowle Park runs
pageSummary: I am running 78km over the 1st 12 days of December because I want to support Marie Curie's vital work
pageSummaryWhat: I am running 78km over the 1st 12 days of December
pageSummaryWhy: I want to support Marie Curie's vital work
story:
I'm a telephone bereavement support volunteer with Marie Curie, and I know that the charity has struggled to maintain their fundraising this year, due to the Covid restrictions. I know a number of people who have hugely benefited from the care they have received at our local West Midlands hospice in Solihull, and I want to help Marie Curie maintain their excellent services there.

I'll be running 1km on 1st December, 2km on 2nd December, .... etc, up to 12km on 12th December. The maths indicate that this amounts to 78km over the 12 days. Most days I'll be running the measured course in Knowle Park from 9am, so come and give me a cheer if you happen to be passing!

Marie Curie themselves write: "Over the past year, dying has become a front-of-mind issue for us all. The pandemic and our ageing population means its never been more pressing to make sure we have the right care and support in place to be able to protect and cherish each other as we reach the final months, weeks, days and hours of our lives."

eventName: Light Up Christmas Campaign, Marie Curie Hospice Garden
pageSummary: To light a lantern in the hospice garden because I'll dedicate it to my colleagues and friends
pageSummaryWhat: To light a lantern in the hospice garden
pageSummaryWhy: I'll dedicate it to my colleagues and friends
story:
I am so proud to work for Marie Curie Hospice, Newcastle.  It's been the most emotionally challenging year. I am also incredibly proud of the strength, humility and sheer kindness of my colleagues have shown during this difficult time. Please help me show how much the hospice means to us and our community. We’re asking as many people as possible, at work, home or school, to help us ‘Light up Christmas’ by pledging to raise £100 – enough to fund 5 hours of nursing care.

For every £100 raised, we’ll light a lantern in the gardens for all our patients and staff to see on Christmas Eve. We will also send one to you to display in your window wherever you are throughout December. You can dedicate your lantern in memory or celebration of a loved one if you like, and every light will make a huge difference to everyone at Marie Curie. 

This year might not be what we hoped or expected but we can still make sure that Marie Curie can be there for our patients and their families by helping us Light up Christmas.

pageSummary: Raising money for Marie Curie because Nan would want us to help
pageSummaryWhy: Nan would want us to help
story:
Tomorrow (19th November) we will say goodbye to Nan in a small, closed ceremony due to the current rules and regulations.

We know that without these regulations, Nan would've had hundreds of people showing their respects tomorrow, and we're sorry that they can't all do this. 

With this in mind, people have been asking us how they can remember Nan, and how they can honour her memory. That's why we've set this page up.

Marie Curie nurses provided care for Nan during her last journey in the kindest way they could. We want other families to be able to have their support, so we'd like to donate to the amazing charity on behalf of Nan.

Thank you so much.

Dennis, Sue + Dave, Debbie + Rob, Emma, Mike + George, Claire, Luke and Evie, Lisa, Jamie + Poppy, and Michelle + Matt.

pageSummary: Running laps of the lake dressed as Daffodils because We're supporting Marie Curie and the work they do
pageSummaryWhat: Running laps of the lake dressed as Daffodils
pageSummaryWhy: We're supporting Marie Curie and the work they do
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page.

On the 23rd of December me and my brother James are going to run laps of Roath park lake, for 12 hours, dressed as daffodils, in memory of our Dad who sadly passed away from a brain tumour on the 23rd of December last year.

With the support of Marie Curie we were able to keep my Dad at home with us as a family until he passed away surrounded by all his closest loved ones. This is something that will always be very special to us as a family.

Marie Curie provided much needed support to all of us during a difficult couple of months.

Even though at the moment it feels like everything has stopped, unfortunately there are still patient's and their families needing support and care as much as ever. We can't imagine what our situation last year would be like if it was now!

Any donation would be much appreciated and will help Marie Curie continue the amazing job they do supporting patient's and their families though difficult times. 

Any support you would like to give will have to be virtual as we don't want to encourage groups of people in the current circumstances. Any messages would be welcome though.

Thanks for taking the time to visit our page.

Mike, James and family

eventName: Dylan’s Kilimanjaro Trek for Marie Curie
story:
In August 2021 I will be climbing Mount Kilimanjaro in aid of Marie Curie. They are an amazing end of life charity that provides a wide range of support, ranging from understanding death and coping with bereavement to facilitating much needed nursing and hospice care. Under the Covid Climate, getting the right care to those who need it has been harder than ever. I have chosen to raise money for Marie Curie as it is a charity that is close to my heart. They work tirelessly everyday to improve the quality of life of those living with a terminal illness and support their families and friends . 

In 2019 my family received the heart breaking news that my Aunt had been diagnosed with stage 4 metastatic Bowel Cancer. Things quickly went from bad to worse. The cancer was aggressive and had spread to her lymph nodes. There were three months between her diagnosis and her passing. There was no time to fully understand what was happening. A week before she died she was moved to a hospice. This is where, we were all given the time, space and support to try to understand and come to terms with what was happening. 

Although nothing could alleviate the pain and trauma that we all went through, it was the nurses and staff at the hospice that provided support and care through the worst time.  

Up until the 29th of August I will be undertaking various fundraising events to help me reach my donation target. I’d like to thank each and every one of you who chooses to donate to this great cause and I’ll be doing my bit on the climb!

story:
Marie Curie Caerphilly Fundraising Group's 12 days of Christmas. 

2020 has been a challenging year for everyone especially those affected by terminal illness. All monies raised from this fundraiser will go straight to supporting Marie Curie's services in Wales. 

This year we have had to adapt our usual fundraising activities and are hosting these Covid safe fundraisers to spread christmas cheer in the community:

  • Mulled Wine & Mince Pies delivery - Friday 11th November
    Enjoy a festive goody bag with mulled wine & a mince pie (non alcoholic alternatives available) for a donation to Marie Curie.

  • Quickstep Fitness 5k & 10k Fun runs w/ Mulled Wine & Mince Pie at finish line - Sunday 13th December 12pm

  • Festive Quiz
    Sent a quiz to complete and send back, donations to Marie Curie.

Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in peoples homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.

pageSummary: Encouraging donations because With support we were able to keep Mum at home.
pageSummaryWhy: With support we were able to keep Mum at home.
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit our JustGiving page to a great charity. Nobody ever really wants to have to ask, but when your in need of help and support it’s great to know they are there.

Although we are grieving the loss of our Mum we are forever grateful for the support of Marie Curie. 

Even though we are all going through an unprecedented worldwide pandemic. With their support we were able to get Mum out of hospital and allow us the opportunity to say all we had to say before she passed. 

This allowed her to go with dignity at home, surrounded by family. 

Thanks for your support. 

Billy, Angela, Lee & Mark

pageSummary: I will be climbing Mt Kilimanjaro, Tanzania
pageSummaryWhat: I will be climbing Mt Kilimanjaro, Tanzania
story:
Hi everyone,

This August I am going to tackle Mt Kilimanjaro, the world's tallest free-standing mountain. All with the aim of helping the work of the amazing Marie Curie Foundation. 

Having spent the past two years of Sixth Form volunteering at a care home close to my school, it taught me to appreciate the work that foundations such as Marie Curie are able to achieve. Marie Curie is able to provide frontline nursing and hospice care, a free support line and a wealth of information and support on all aspects of dying, death and bereavement. The money which is raised will go directly to caring services, research and campaigning for better end of life care. Remember every penny counts!

There is no better way for me to fundraise, than a trek. Since I can remember my mum has been telling me stories of the adventures she had and in 2016, we walked over 300 miles for the World Land Trust, but this time I am going bigger and better. I am super excited to tackle this incredible mountain and any contributions to the work of Marie Curie we can gather in the process will be greatly appreciated!

To keep up with my fundraising efforts and adventures please do keep an eye on this page as well as follow my instagram @adventures4mariecurie.

Thank you again for all your generous support! 

Lots of Love

Bella xoxo

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

I am lucky enough to not have any family members that have required the amazing services that Marie Curie provides. As well as both of my parents working in the medical industry, I have also worked in hospitals during COVID-19 pandemic and because of this I have been made acutely aware of the importance of high quality end of life care and it's substantial effect it can have on the patient and their family. Unfortunately, family friends have also  been affected by diseases such as cancer but an incredible amount of support came from Marie Curie and helped to make the families time together as comfortable and happy as possible.

As a regular partaker in fundraising for charities I would love to continue supporting these amazing organizations. In the new age of coronavirus, charities are in need of our support more than ever. Due to worldwide restrictions events that could of previously ran can no longer, therefore resulting in a decline of fundraising.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. charity.registrationNumber: 207994 (England & Wales) and SC038731 (Scotland)
pageSummary: Donations instead of funeral flowers because of the wonderful care they gave Dad.
pageSummaryWhy: of the wonderful care they gave Dad.
story:
When dad was first diagnosed with cancer earlier this year the nurses at Marie Curie helped us by caring for dad at night. The support  they gave us during this time was invaluable as we came to terms with dad's condition.

Marie Curie rely on donations to enable them to offer vital services for people living with a terminal illness and their families.   

Instead of funeral flowers please consider donating to this brilliant organisation.

Devoted husband of 70 years to Zia (nee Abraham),  beloved father of Lyle, Clayton and Wanda and father-in-law of Steve.  Dad leaves behind a huge gap in our lives.  

He joins his parents, Patrick and Mildred, sister Ruth, brothers Donald, James and Charles who have already passed.  

He will be missed by his many cousins, nieces and nephews.

pageSummary: We are asking for donations because of their amazing work.
story:
Sadly on the 28th of October 2020 Shelley passed away.

We have lost a much loved and hugely valued colleague and dear friend. Her charisma, sense of fun and humour will be missed.

As her illness progressed she was amazingly strong, brave and, as ever, graceful to the end.

Unfortunately the current restrictions on numbers allowed at funerals due to Covid19 meant that many, many people who would have been there were not able to attend.

The family want to give Shelley's many friends and colleagues the opportunity to make a donation to Marie Curie in her memory.

Thanks for taking the time to visit this JustGiving page.

pageSummary: Hamilton's donating in lieu of  Christmas presents because they were superb in helping Billy & his family
pageSummaryWhat: Hamilton's donating in lieu of  Christmas presents
pageSummaryWhy: they were superb in helping Billy & his family
story:
Christmas 2020 will be an unusual one as has the whole of 2020 in general.  This year we have all really realised the strength of the NHS and the carers who help people who are sick and in need of palliative care.  The Hamilton family have decided as we cannot all get together as a family due to the current restrictions, that they would like to donate to Marie Curie in lieu of Christmas presents.  They were invaluable to the family in Billy's last few months and we feel appreciation is deserving.

This year all we really want is to be able to come together again as a family, give each other a hug and spend some valuable time catching up, playing with children, having a bit of craic - just as Billy would have loved.....minus the sneaky pint of Guinness!  

Please donate whatever you feel appropriate and it can be kept anonymous if you wish.  Marie Curie will be ever grateful for our help.

charity.description: Marie Curie provides care and support for people living with any terminal illness across the UK. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
charity.registrationNumber: 207994 (England & Wales) and SC038731 (Scotland)
story:
Weve been caring for local people in this way for more than 50 years, now. Every single day at the hospice is an extraordinary day. 

We listen, support and give high-quality care during what can be a difficult, challenging and distressing time. And we get to know people as individuals, find out what makes them happy, and help to make those things happen.

That might mean sitting with them in the hospice garden, or arranging for their pet to visit them at the hospice. We focus on the special things that bring people joy.

We also provide important support for carers and families, including bereavement support and counselling.

We need to raise £6,150 per day to run the hospice, so every penny counts. Thank you for helping to make sure more people with a terminal illness in and around Belfast, get the care and support they need. If you would like to find out more about raising funds for our hospice, visit: https://www.mariecurie.org.uk/help/hospice-care/hospices/belfast/fundraise

pageSummary: I want to raise money for Light up Christmas because they looked after my grandma so well
pageSummaryWhat: I want to raise money for Light up Christmas
pageSummaryWhy: they looked after my grandma so well
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

On the 16th July 2019 my grandma sadly passed away and lost her 2 year battle with cancer. She was the most amazing mam, daughter, sister, grandma and friend to so many people who loved her very much. Linda only spent 8 days in the Marie Curie Hospice in Newcastle where she received the most amazing love and care from every staff member, who also gave us, the family and friends unbelievable support. We will never be able to say how thankful we are for the nurses at Marie Curie and the amount of care they gave to us. 

Due to this year being as terrible as everyone knows it has been, the hospice’s have suffered hugely with running costs which is so sad to hear because every family and individual deserves the support that we were given and will be forever grateful for. This year Marie Curie have a ‘Light up Christmas’ campaign, where if £100 is raised for the charity then they will light up a personalised lantern in remembrance of your lost loved one. Raising that amount of money for such an amazing, helpful charity and being able to have a remembrance lantern shining on Christmas eve, where she gained her wings, would mean the absolute world to us. She is missed more and more  every day❤️

Thank you so much for reading and thank you even more for donating if you have it means so much to us. 24hour End of life care is so unexpected, but so important that it is well funded so all of our loved ones can continue to gain their wings with the same care my grandma received.

eventName: Kunzo's Everest Base Camp Trek for Marie Curie
pageSummary: I will be trekking to Mt Everest Base Camp
pageSummaryWhat: I will be trekking to Mt Everest Base Camp
story:
Thank you for visiting my fundraising page! I will take you with me on my journey updating you on the fundraising, training and trekking.

As a team of Swansea University students, we will be trekking to Mount Everest Base camp in September 2021. We will start in Kathmandu and travel to Lukla where we will begin our 11 day trek through amazing sites like Phakding, Namche Bazaar by the peaks of Khumbu, Thyangboche and more! We will be reaching 5164m above sea level!

The money that we raise will help fund Marie Curie, a leading researcher in palliative care in the UK, to continue their amazing work for patients of terminal illness and for their families, especially in the current climate with the pandemic. The work of the nurses goes far beyond just clinical, emotional and physical care so hopefully we can raise this money to help these heroes go the extra mile.

Any amount donated is very much appreciated and is still progress towards our goal :)

story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page

I am a Marie Curie volunteer and at this time of year I would normally be taking part in supermarket collections over the festive season but due to COVID-19 this cannot happen , so I have decided to set myself a little running challenge to try and  raise money instead of the collections where the public are always so generous ❤️. 

I have based the challenge on the 12 days of Christmas 🎄 🎅🏻.  In the song there are a total of 78 gifts which my true love gave to me , so I am going to hopefully run 78km in 12 days ( 6.5 km or more per day ) . 

I hope you can support me in my challenge . 🏃‍♀️ 🏃‍♀️

Any amount donated to my page would be much appreciated to help towards the amazing care and support Marie Curie give to people with terminal illness and there families .

eventName: Vonnie's pay for a Christmas Dinner
pageSummary: I am raising funds to pay for 20 Xmas Day Dinners because we need your support more then ever before.
pageSummaryWhat: I am raising funds to pay for 20 Xmas Day Dinners
pageSummaryWhy: we need your support more then ever before.
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page!

The reality is that this Christmas will be the last for our Marie Curie patients in our communities and hospices across the country. It will cost approx £7.50 to pay for a Christmas Day Dinner for a patient in our 9 Marie Curie hospices across the UK. Please support me in reaching my target of 20 dinners to support the charity at this time of need.  

Ever picture tells a story, and this smiley photo from last year shows how important our Marie Curie staff & volunteers are in caring for our patients and families every single day of the year. Please help us make those final memories for both patient and family as bearable as possible.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. story: Molly will be 100 years old on 21st December, instead of receiving any presents from friends and family she would love a donation to Marie Curie instead.  Molly has asked for these donations as she witnessed the great care and support given to her sister Peggy and Peggy's immediate family when she was in need of Marie Curie nurses.  Molly also knows other friends who have been in similar situations who have also recognised the importance of the services Marie Curie provides.  Any donations will be greatly appreciated by Molly.

pageSummary: Cycling from London to Paris in 3 days because I believe in a better end of life for all.
pageSummaryWhat: Cycling from London to Paris in 3 days
pageSummaryWhy: I believe in a better end of life for all.
story:
Thank you for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. I am a veterinary student at university of Bristol hoping to make a difference in 2021. I have decided to take on the challenge of cycling from London to Paris in just 3 days to raise money for Marie Curie. Marie Curie are an incredible charity that provide care and support for people living with any terminal illness, and their families. 

In July, I will be departing London for three tough days of cycling through scenic countryside and different types of terrain, on a route that takes over 280km from Greenwich Park to the foot of the Eiffel Tower, in a whirlwind cycling challenge. I hope to raise a grand total of £1500 over the next 6 months. If you believe in a better end of life for all, please donate here today. 

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Our nurses work night and day in people’s homes and our hospices offer specialist care. We also support people emotionally, provide practical information, and match them with trained volunteers.
charity.name: Marie Curie
charity.registrationNumber: 207994 (England & Wales) and SC038731 (Scotland)
story:
Hiya! 

At the end of August next year, I will be departing with Choose a Challenge on a six day trek up Mount Kilimanjaro to raise money for Marie Curie UK.

Kilimanjaro is 5895m above sea level! This adds to the challenge significantly as the altitude increases and breathing becomes more difficult. The summit itself can reach lows of -29 degrees, but this is all part of the challenge for an amazing cause!

Marie Curie UK does phenomenal work caring and supporting those with terminal illnesses and their families. This work is exceptional and necessary at the best of times but especially in our current climate of Covid-19, their work could not be more valuable.

This journey will be both physically and mentally challenging but it is something I am proud to be doing to support such a worthy cause.

Please donate whatever you can to the amazing people at Marie Curie UK so that they may continue their invaluable work.

Thank you so much for your support, 

Lori Weaver x

pageSummary: I am leading a cycle of 280km from London to Paris because I love a challenge and a good cause!
pageSummaryWhat: I am leading a cycle of 280km from London to Paris
pageSummaryWhy: I love a challenge and a good cause!
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page. I have paired up with Bristol RAG and Choose a Challenge to lead a group of Bristol students for a 280km cycle from Greenwhich park in London to the Eiffel Tower in Paris and raise money for Marie Curie along the way!

Marie Curie is the UK's leading end of life charity providing nursing and hospice care, as well as free counselling and support for families on all aspects of death, dying and bereavement. I feel that this is especially relevant in the current global pandemic where the choice of dying in a hospital alone or at home with your families without the medical and emotional support of nurses and doctors is one being faced by thousands of people. Marie Curie cares for more than 40 000 terminally ill patients annually.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

story:
Hello! Thank you for visiting my JustGiving page and considering to donate to this cause.

In 2021/2022 (virus dependent) I will be trekking up to Everest Base Camp for the charity Marie Curie. 

Life may look like it's starting up again soon, but for people with a terminal diagnosis, and families devastated by loss, there is no going back to 'normal'. There are very few families who are not touched by terminal illness and the grief that comes with it, myself included. Marie Curie is an end of life charity, providing nursing, hospice care, and other support on all aspects of death. We never know when it may strike our own families, but I would like to support this charity so if ever I need it, it will be there. 

I will keep you updated with some fundraising challenges I hope to undertake throughout the year for some entertainment! I would be extremely grateful for your donations.

Donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

pageSummaryWhat: I am cycling the Caledonia Etape in May 2021
pageSummaryWhy: I want to help raise funds for this charity.
story:
The UK’s original closed road sportive is back – Etape Caledonia 2021! Etape Caledonia has attracted more than 35,000 riders since its debut in 2007. With 5,500 places on offer each year, this sell out event attracts riders from all over the country to take on one of the most breathtaking rides through the spectacular Scottish Highlands.#EtapeCaledonia

I have done the Caledonia Etape before- the long one on my own- but this year I am doing the shorter one with John ( who supported me the last time and this time we will cycle together) in memory of a lovely woman who sadly died far too soon in May 2020. Laura was only 43,  in my book group and we all miss her dearly. This cycle, and all that I raise, is in memory of a much loved and missed young woman. A small gesture that will help others .

eventName: Iceland Trek 2021 for Hampstead Hospice and London
pageSummary: I'm doing a four day trek of 50 km across Iceland because I want to give myself a challenge in my 60th year
pageSummaryWhat: I'm doing a four day trek of 50 km across Iceland
pageSummaryWhy: I want to give myself a challenge in my 60th year
story:
Thanks for taking the time to visit my JustGiving page.

As I was approaching my 60th birthday I started thinking about how lucky I was to be in such a good health. It made me think more often about my grandmother who I share the same birthday with, but who I never knew. She died before reaching my age, only six months after I was born. I'm sure given today's advantages in medical treatments and care, she not only could have lived longer but in addition would have had the comfort of care and support through her illness. 

In a relatively short period of time, when I was in my thirties, my grandfather was admitted to the hospice in Hampstead, where he received palliative treatment and care. The support he received at the later stages of his life made it such a different experience for him and his immediate family. 

Charities, such as Marie Curie, are so invaluable at these times. Furthermore, donating through JustGiving is simple, fast and totally secure. Your details are safe with JustGiving - they'll never sell them on or send unwanted emails. Once you donate, they'll send your money directly to the charity. So it's the most efficient way to donate - saving time and cutting costs for the charity.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
pageSummary: Raising funds because they are saving lives every day around our coast
pageSummaryWhy: they are saving lives every day around our coast
story:
Thank you for visiting our JustGiving page. 

Largs Lifeboat Station  has a  B class, Atlantic 85 lifeboat, B-854 R A Wilson  and the volunteer crew are available 24/7 for anyone who needs their help and are always be there to answer that call.

To keep a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue across Scotland is costly and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the pounds start to add up. It costs an average of £155k to run a lifeboat station in Scotland but this year, with the implications of Covid-19, we haven't been able to fundraise to keep our lifeboats afloat.

We rely on donations to help RNLI crews save lives at sea - your donation to this page will help support the running costs of stations in the Scotland, including here in Largs.


Photo Credit: RNLI/Alasdair Woods

story:
Clontarf RNLI is 45 years old and has faced many challenges but none as big as this year when Covid19 restrictions shut all of our fundraising activities. This of course includes our Christmas day swim. Last year we had over 300 swimmers and had hoped to match that number this year. The swim is an integral part of our annual fundraising which means the cancellation has a big impact on our finances.


Clontarf RNLI wish to thank our supporters and wish them and their families a happy and safe Christmas.


Should you still like to support the RNLI please use the link below.

Train one to save many.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. 

RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.

Thank you.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
Our role is to raise funds to support & maintain the Workington Lifeboats & Crew #saving lives at sea

There are 29 volunteer crew & 22 volunteer fundraisers. We have two lifeboats a Shannon class "Dorothy May White" & an ILB "D" class "John F Mortimer".

The boats are based in Workington on the Prince of Wales dock covering the shore & sea of West Cumbria. The station has been in service since 1886.

The Fundraisers usually have a full programme of events but since March due to COVID-19 we have been unable to organise any events. Despite our fundraising activities being cancelled we still need to raise money to support the lifeboats & crew.

The crew are still on call 24/7 during the pandemic keeping the West Cumbrian coast safe.

Please help us keep the boats afloat with any donation you can make.

Thank you for your support.

pageSummary: I am going to run 40 miles before I'm 40 because I want to raise money in memory of someone special
pageSummaryWhat: I am going to run 40 miles before I'm 40
pageSummaryWhy: I want to raise money in memory of someone special
story:
2020 has been a tough year for many. Just before the pandemic, we also lost someone very special. I would like to try to finish this year with something positive.

Four months ago I couldn't have run for 40 seconds without stopping. I did the Couch 2 5k challenge and now running has become a part of my life. I turn 40 around Christmas and out on a run this morning I decided I would like to do a run for charity. I will run 40 or more miles (not in one go) before my birthday dressed in 80s clothing and a rainbow tutu with equally garish socks. 

I have chosen to raise money for the RNLI because not only is it a charity that does so much in our local community, but it was also a charity close to a late family member's heart. 

If anyone could spare a few pennies to sponsor me, I would be most grateful. 

If at any point due to Covid or illness I have to self-isolate etc, I will add the time lost to the end of the challenge.

pageSummary: Running 100 miles in a week because every little helps.
story:
So I've signed up for a virtual running event run by the wonderful people at Centurion Running and, if my body lets me, will be running 100 miles over this week coming (that's just over 14 miles a day).

If this grabs your attention for a even just a few seconds then I'd like to ask if you'd perhaps spare a thought and perhaps a few quid for the people who are out around our coasts saving lives 24/7/365 in the RNLI.  I run past the RNLI station in Littlehampton all the time and right now their income has dropped significantly thanks to the pandemic so I thought it might be nice to use my moment of madness to see if we can help reverse that situation even just a little bit.

Thanks very much if you can spare something for the RNLI, it will help me to push through the miles if I know that something genuinely good is happening off the back of it.

If you need to know any more about the RNLI then please read on and THANK YOU!

Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place. Thank you.

pageSummary: Walking in the garden to stay healthy and happy because It's her favourite Charity
pageSummaryWhat: Walking in the garden to stay healthy and happy
story:
We love and miss our grandma Linda so much and will not be seeing her for Christmas, and we know that she has found lockdown really hard. She has type II diabetes and can be harmed a lot by Covid, and so she has been alone in her house with grandad since March 2020. She feels insecure about walking around the village, so she has started walking around her back garden 12 times per day, with lots of support from us and grandad. 

We think that this is great and we are hoping that this will help her feel happier and healthier, and we are donating to RNLI as a Christmas surprise for her (She grew up in Bridlington and we know that this Charity is very close to her heart). She doesn't know yet but we hope that she will be very happy when she finds out.

Merry Christmas to all of you from Molly and Julia xxx

PS. Click the button to donate if you like.
title: Linda's Garden Laps
rememberedPersonSummary.name: NA
Name: Linda's Garden Laps
ProfileWhat: Walking in the garden to stay healthy and happy

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story: Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place. Thank you.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
Right, I’m going to attempt to haul my fat carcass along 8 miles of the Jurassic Costal path for the RNLI Reindeer run on 12th December. 

Donations & fundraising events like this help to maintain continued lifesaving operations by the brave boys & girls in the crews. 

It’s for a good cause with the added benefit of knowing I’ll be in turbo clip, blowing out my arse, & regretting my life decisions by mile 1, so chuck a couple of quid in the pot.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
pageSummary: 10km coastal virtual Reindeer Run because The RNLI provides a vital emergency service.
pageSummaryWhy: The RNLI provides a vital emergency service.
story:
We’re taking part in the Virtual Reindeer Run 2020! 

My eldest sister, Hilary, is a fundraiser for RNLI Minehead. We know, therefore, what a difficult year it has been for fundraising. Yet we also know that the need for the incredible, lifesaving work the RNLI do has not lessened.

Living in a coastal area, we are acutely aware of how easily people can find themselves in trouble in the sea or on the cliffs and dunes of our coastline. The RNLI provides an amazing emergency and rescue service and we want to do anything we can to ensure that they can continue to assist people who are in peril. 

Every year, approaching Christmas, our family get together for a Christmas gathering. This year, because of Covid, we can’t do this. Instead we have decided to form a team for the RNLI virtual Reindeer Run - we can all connect through a shared participation in both the running event and raising money for such a great cause. 

The Hewlett-Robbins Reindeer Runners plan to do a 10km coastal run on Saturday 12th December. Please, if you feel able, sponsor us - every donation, however small, will help!

Thank you!

story:
We are donning our antlers and running hooves for Reindeer Run - the RNLI’s festive virtual run - to help Rookie the Reindeer save lives at sea.

Hi, thanks for visiting our page. 

Living on the coast, we've witnessed the RNLI in action on more than one occasion. They risk their lives every time they enter the water to save others. They're also an important cause personally as our family are members of the local boat clubs and spend a lot of time out at sea.

As the RNLI are volunteers they need funding to stay afloat (pun intended!), so anything you can offer would be massively appreciated to help these amazing people keep saving lives! 

Thank you 🙂

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
pageSummary: Running 10K because they save many lives and do amazing work.
pageSummaryWhy: they save many lives and do amazing work.
story:
Too many people are still drowning. 

As a diver, and having grown up by the sea, I am particularly aware of the power of the sea and how crucial the RNLI can be in rescuing people and saving lives. 

More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.Thank you.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
We as a family are donning our antlers and running hooves for Reindeer Run - the RNLI’s festive virtual run - to help Rookie the Reindeer save lives at sea.

The RNLI is a charity close to our hearts and we know how covid has hit them so we want to do what we can. We will be running as a family for 1 km and then Mummy reindeer will take the reins for the 10 more kms.  We know many people have been hit financially but would appreciate greatly if anyone would like to donate to this amazing charity.

Thank you and Happy Christmas from us all xx

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. 

RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.

Thank you.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
eventName: WsM RNLI Harmonia Sacra Carol Service
pageSummary: We are fundraising for because local volunteers need a new station desperately
pageSummaryWhy: local volunteers need a new station desperately
story:
During these difficult times it is not easy to enjoy the season and also difficult to support our local lifesavers.

Harmonia Sacra, a local critically acclaimed choir have kindly agreed to sing carols at a carols by candlelight service at All Saints' Church, WsM with Bristol Brass on the evening of Wednesday 16 December. There will not be an audience but the event will be streamed and all proceeds go to Weston RNLI. The details of the streaming will be announced later.

Candles will be lit in the church. As part of this event the RNLI is offering the opportunity to have one of the candles dedicated to a loved one who is no longer with us. To achieve this make a donation on this page and add the name of the loved one. A list will be prepared which will be displayed with the candles on the night.

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
I am donning my antlers and running hooves for Reindeer Run - the RNLI’s festive virtual run - to help Rookie the Reindeer save lives at sea.

Normally this is held at Moors Valley but as it’s now a virtual event I thought it would be fitting to start and finish at the RNLI itself. Sully and I will start at the RNLI Support Centre in Poole and run round Holes Bay via Upton Country Park, Hamworthy Park and Poole Lifeboat Station.

I haven’t set a big target as I know lots of people are struggling, I hope a tenner a mile is achievable. Every bit will help this brilliant charity continue saving lives and helping people.
title: Virtual Reindeer Run - Holes Bay 10K

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
pageSummary: By sending ecards you are raising money because they are saving lives every day around our coasts
pageSummaryWhat: By sending ecards you are raising money
pageSummaryWhy: they are saving lives every day around our coasts
story:
Your generosity this Christmas will help bring our volunteer crew home safely to their loved ones. Volunteers on the frontline launch into winter winds, freezing waters and huge waves. They need training and kit plus extra PPE, like masks and gloves. And as a charity, the RNLI relies on kind donations to provide them with this. But income is expected to be down by millions this year.

So as a special Christmas gift, will you consider donating to the RNLI instead of sending physical Christmas cards this year? You can end this year with kindness, knowing that you’ve helped keep lifeboat volunteers ready and able to save lives. They are so grateful to have you beside them.

Funds raised on this page will go towards Scottish lifeboat station running costs.

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
pageSummary: I am swimming in a frozen lake in Westbury
pageSummaryWhat: I am swimming in a frozen lake in Westbury
story:
As most of you know, my Dad - Ray Parsons passed away this year.

In the winter of 1979 - Recorded as 28th Coldest since records began. On boxing day of this year, the minehole lake (Eden Vale lake) of Westbury was frozen over solid. My Dad donned his wetsuit and braved the extreme cold conditions. He climbed into the lake, breaking the frozen surface and continued out into the lake breaking the ice. He was raising money for guide dogs for the blind.

I will be following his lead and doing the same on Boxing day this year (providing the lake is frozen over on this day, if not, I shall do it on a different day when conditions suit).

I am raising money for the RNLI (Royal National Lifeboat Institution)

Too many people are still drowning. More than ever we need the RNLI’s help. As a charity, the RNLI depends on our donations so it can go on saving lives and keeping us and our loved ones safe. RNLI lifesavers are our lifeline. They’re the lifeboat crews who provide 24-hour search and rescue right around the UK and Ireland. The lifeguards keeping watch on 240 of the busiest beaches in the UK and Channel Islands. And the RNLI safety teams and educators working tirelessly to stop people getting into trouble in the first place.Thank you.
title: Charles's Icebreaker
rememberedPersonSummary.name: Raymond Parsons
Name: Charles's Icebreaker
ProfileWhat: I am swimming in a frozen lake in Westbury

charity.description: RNLI volunteer lifeboat crews provide a 24-hour search and rescue service all around the UK and Ireland, while lifeguards keep a careful watch on the UK’s busiest beaches. RNLI lifesaving and drowning prevention depend on supporter fundraising and the generous donations that you and others give.
charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
Our RNLI lifeboats in Ireland protect hundreds of communities through our 24-hour search and rescue service. They rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from.

Irelands unrivalled coasts and inland waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike, with millions travelling to enjoy them, and work on them each year. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

Keeping a modern fleet of lifeboats maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue from all 36 of the lifeboat stations in Ireland is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the euros start to add up. It costs an average of 165k to run lifeboat stations in Ireland but this year, with the implications of Covid-19, we havent been able to fundraise to keep our lifeboats afloat.

We rely on donations from you the public to continue saving lives at sea and on inland waters - your donation to this page will help support the running of the following lifeboat stations in Ireland:

Achill Island, Aran Islands, Arklow, Arranmore, Ballycotton, Ballyglass, Baltimore, Bundoran, Castletownbere, Clifden, Clogher Head, Courtmacsherry Harbour, Courtown, Crosshaven, Dun Laoghaire, Dunmore East, Fenit, Fethard, Galway, Helvick Head, Howth, Kilmore Quay, Kilrush, Kinsale, Lough Derg, Lough Ree, Lough Swilly, Rosslare Harbour, Skerries, Sligo Bay, Tramore, Union Hall, Valentia, Wexford, Wicklow and Youghal

charity.name: RNLI - Royal National Lifeboat Institution
story:
We are the Crosshaven Fundraising Branch. We run several events throughout the year including our famous coffee morning held in the Royal Cork Yacht Club, Flag days & Fish Supper. While we also sell RNLI souvenirs, and Christmas cards. However, we haven’t been able to take part in our traditional fundraising this year and rely on donations from the public to continue saving lives. Your donation will help support the run Crosshaven Lifeboat.  

The Lifeboat Station was established in 2000 on the Owenabue River. Crosshaven Lifeboat Station operates an inshore B class Atlantic 85 lifeboat. Our RNLI lifeboats in Ireland protect hundreds of communities through our 24-hour search and rescue service. They rely on the safest, most reliable lifeboats and modern stations to launch from.

Irelands unrivalled coasts and inland waters are valued by local communities and visitors alike. But the water remains an unpredictable environment that can catch people out. People will always need our help and we will always be there to answer that call.

Keeping our lifeboat maintained, fuelled and ever ready to go to the rescue is expensive and we rely entirely on voluntary donations to ensure this service is maintained. Add to that crew training and kit, and the euros start to add up. During the pandemic we have still been offering a lifesaving service and are continuing to raise vital funds.
